sourceString: Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower, suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.
targetString: Kë cï thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ  kek të ye SARS-CoV dhiɛ̈th thïn, dhiɛ̈nh SARS-CoV-2 atɔ̈u piiny, ku e yen ye nyuɔth lɔn lëu bï yen dom kɔc gup.

sourceString: Presumably, it has already been adapted to another host close to humans.
targetString: Thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ic de, yenn acï dom apath tën kë dɛ̈t thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ kek kɔc.

sourceString: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.
targetString: Të met SARS-CoV-2, kën alɛ̈u bï luɔ̈i alɔŋ MERS-CoV, këye kë cï dom apath tën thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l.

sourceString: Theoretically, it is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.
targetString: Të ŋïc yen, të ye köm cɛɛth thïn abï wäl ku käk guop tiit ice tuany SARS-CoV-2 cɔl acï lɔc yɔ̈k.

sourceString: Second, the large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, thereby increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution, which is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs when the conditions become appropriate.
targetString: Rɔu, abaŋ dït RNA CoV ic e lui ke cïn ke rɛc guop ic të ye guop rot waar thïn e dhiëëth ku nuɛ̈tnuɛt, ku e yen tuany cɔl ajuak rot alɔŋ lääi cï thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ku e yen kë path tën kuat CoV të cï aliir ic piath.

sourceString: This is supported by the copious unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.
targetString: Kën aye akuën cï looi ke ŋaany kuɔny cɔ̈k kä tɔ̈u ye kɛ̈c ku të ye protin lui thïn cï kek waar iic alɔŋ 3' të ye guop lui thïn

sourceString: Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
targetString: Diäk, kuat CoV aa rɔ̈t waar ku aa rɔ̈t wäc kamken dhaman RNA të ye kek yen "kuany-thïn" bïk lui.

sourceString: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
targetString: Tën të ye käm rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn ke ye kën käŋ liääp, wɛ̈c rot e rot looi dhaman thok ebën të tek CoV RNA rot.

sourceString: Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
targetString: Të thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ RNA ku luɔi den alɛ̈u bï rɔ̈t mat ku bïk kuat CoV yam bɛ̈i.

sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
targetString: Acï kë cï kuen nyuɔth lɔn nuɛ̈tnuɛ̈t HCoV-HKU1 ku HCoV-OC43, acï yɔ̈k, agut CoV lääi cïmen SL-CoV ku batCoV-HKU9.

sourceString: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
targetString: Të ye köm rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn ku tekde rot piny

sourceString: Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
targetString: Tën dhɔ̈ɔ̈l kä diäk ye köm yɔ̈k cï ke luel nhial të tui, të ye köm rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn kek ye yen rɛ̈ɛ̈r ye guop e kë pɛth dɛ̈t lɛ̈u bï kɔc kony të ye köm rot tɛk piny thïn lääi loi thook gup.

sourceString: Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
targetString: E tën, mɛ̈n ic SARS-CoV acï nyai ke ye kït, ku acï yic nyuɔth ke alɔŋ kuɛ̈nykuɛ̈ny path dhaman loi të ye köm rot tɛk lääi loi thook gup.

sourceString: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.
targetString: Tëcït tën thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ kɔ̈u cï looi kam kɔc cï kek tek thook ku SARS-CoV aŋɔu, acï tak ka SARS-CoV e lac dom käjuëc gup, ku e dhiɛ̈th alɔŋ RBD protin S.

sourceString: Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
targetString: RBD tɔ̈u S protin CoV e liääp kek riɛm ku acï guop ye köm rɛ̈ɛ̈r kuany.

sourceString: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
targetString: SARS-CoV ic, RBD atɔ̈u nimra 318 le 510 amino acid abaŋ S1, ku e rɔt nuɛt ACE2 raan ic ku e yen tëde tën dhɔ̈ɔ̈l ye köm tɛ̈k.

sourceString: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
targetString: RBD SARS-CoV alɛ̈u bï ACE2 tɔ̈u lääi gup ŋic, ku aala iic alïïk, aŋau, lɔk ku jɔ̈ŋ rakuun, ku tek piny tuany kam lääi cï liääp puöl.

sourceString: In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
targetString: Ku yic, amino acid kä 6 aa kek cï ke tïŋ ke looi thöök tën ran ku köm aŋau cï tek thok RBD ic ku käŋ kä 4 aa tɔ̈u të ye kek rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn ku bï ACE2 lui.

sourceString: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
targetString: SARS-CoV aŋau ala K479N ku S487T dhiɛ̈th RBD, ku e mäth den juakic spike protin kek ACE2 tɔ̈u raan guop.

sourceString: In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
targetString: Të luel yen wɛ̈l kök, awɛ̈r ic amino acid kärɔu abï ic dhiɛl riɛl to köm ku bï dom raan guop.

sourceString: It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
targetString: Eke path ku bï ŋic lɔn rɔm SARS-CoV-2 ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye riɛm ke cath thïn kek SARS-CoV.

sourceString: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
targetString: Abaŋ 30% SARS-CoV-2 tek ic kek SARS-CoV alɔŋ S1 abaŋ protin S aye nyuɔth ka mäth protin S kek ACE2 raan acï rɔt war.

sourceString: Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
targetString: Ku adhïl, kë cï cryo-EM kuen aye nyuɔth ka 10 le 20 abaŋ mäth ce ic dol kën nuɛ̈tnuɛ̈t kën tën kën kam ACE2 raan ku protin S SARS-CoV.

sourceString: It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
targetString: Abï piath ku bï ŋic lɔn le yen kë bï wïc ku bï SARS-CoV-2 rɔt tɛk piny.

sourceString: Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
targetString: Kë kɔc tut emɛ̈nɛ̈, HCoV-NL63 e rot mat kek ACE2 ku kek abaŋ S loi thok.

sourceString: There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
targetString: Anaŋ käjuëc kök ye HCoV rɛ̈ɛ̈r ke gup, cïmen aminopeptidase N ke ye ke;n HCoV-229E, ku 9-O akut acid lui guop ic ke ye kën HCoV-OC43

sourceString: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
targetString: Kek aalɛ̈u bï ke kuën rin kuat CoV dom kɔc gup apath wën cï kek tɛk piny e lääi rɛ̈ɛ̈r kek ke gup.

sourceString: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
targetString: Ku kë mɛt thïn alɔŋ käk dom guop ic, kën bɛ̈n bei tek rot piny lääi loi thok gup alɔŋ kuat HCoV aye mac kë dɛ̈t ɣäc ku käk cï pɛ̈n.

sourceString: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
targetString: Kë wääc protin kam kɔc ku ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye kuat HCoV yɔ̈k thïn cïmen aliɛ̈k, thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l baai ku luɔk aalɛ̈u bïk tuany tɛk piny.

sourceString: HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
targetString: Kuat HCoV aalɛ̈u bïk käk ye kek rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn dom ku rɛc kä kek ku naŋ të tek käm rɔ̈t piny lääi loi thook gup.

sourceString: In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
targetString: Ku rin kën, kën käk guop cɔl a lui alɔŋ muɣɛm te ye köm rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn aŋuɔt ŋot kïc tïŋ ku tɛ̈u akutde ic.

sourceString: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.
targetString: Lui CRISPR bï ke SARS-CoV-2 tïŋ të ye yen lui thïn guop ic ku käk cï kek pɛ̈n aa lɛ̈i bï naŋ kë bï kä.

sourceString: Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
targetString: Ke wïc bï rot lac looi alɔŋ kuat HCoV: bi kɔc dhuk piny ic.

sourceString: The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
targetString: Juɛëc ye bat CoVs juëc e kuat HCoVs cɔl ajuak rɔ̈t aya.

sourceString: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
targetString: Ku rin kën, kuat bat CoVs e yen të ye kuat HCoVs yɔ̈k thïn.

sourceString: In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
targetString: Ku kë mɛt thïn, dhiɛ̈th ye köm dhiɛ̈th ku nuɛ̈tnuɛ̈tde aa ke HCoV cɔl a jɔk rot ku aa kek lui keye dhɔ̈ɔ̈l kärɔu e dhël kën ic.

sourceString: For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
targetString: Cïmen, yɔ̈kyɔ̈k wula mär protin e naŋ kë ye looi ku bï të ye köm lui thïn kek aliir cɔ̈k piny.

sourceString: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.
targetString: Kam SARS-CoV protin, ORF8 acï tak lɔn ye yen muɣɛm dömde kɔc gup, ke SARS-CoV thääny thok ke käm aliik cï tek thok ku aacï yɔ̈k ke cï rɔ̈t mat ORF8 protin ic.

sourceString: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
targetString: Coth wei 29-nucleotide të ye kuat SARS-CoV acï yɔ̈k rïŋ cï lel thok mɛ̈nɛ̈ jɔk tuany rot tën kɔc.

sourceString: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
targetString: Coth wei acï ORF8 ku bi ya ORF8a ku ORF8b ku acï tak bï të köm rɔt jak thïn ku e yen lääi wääc.

sourceString: Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Ku e tën, kuat SARS-CoV ala anyïköl nuɛ̈tnuɛ̈t rɔt ke kuat dhiɛ̈ɛ̈th alpa - ku kuat gamma-CoV, ku e yen tën acï abaŋ thiin kor cï rɔ̈t nuet tïŋ thïn RNA polymerase ic.

sourceString: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
targetString: Të ye kek rɔ̈t nuet thïn acï yɔ̈k nsp9 ic, ku abaŋ dït nsp10, ku abaŋ nsp14.

sourceString: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
targetString: Cïmen deaya, acï nyuɔth ka tuɛny MERS-CoV acï dhɔ̈ɔ̈l ye kek rɔ̈t nuet yɔ̈k kam kuat dhiɛ̈th loi thook, ku e rɛ̈ɛ̈r thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l baai pan Saudi Arabia.

sourceString: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
targetString: Tën SARS-CoV ku MERS-CoV, të ye kuat HCoVs rɔ̈t nuɛt thïn acï tïŋ , ku e yen të ye kuat HCoVs rɔ̈t nuɛt thïn kek kuat CoV lääi kök alɔŋ të ke cak thïn gup ken iic.

sourceString: It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.
targetString: Awïc bï ŋiɛc looi apath rin kuɛ̈nykuɛ̈ny alɛ̈u bï awɛ̈r rot cï wïc looi käm guop ic, ku e lac bɛ̈n bei të pɛ̈l käm alɔŋ kuɛ̈nykuɛny cï looi riɛl, cïmen të ye të ye kek rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn lui thïn.

sourceString: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
targetString: Ku kën yen nyuɔth yen kë cï rot looi e määr ORF4 HCoV-229E iic ebën, ku aŋuɔt awïc coth wei nucleotide kärɔu.

sourceString: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
targetString: Ku ke ORF4 kïc riäk lɛ̈u bï tïŋ alïïk ku käm thɔ̈rɔ̈l gup thääny thook kek HCoV-229E, alpha-CoV alpaka e nucleotide tök yen aye nyuɔth tɛ̈ɛ̈u thïn, ku e yen käk coth wei ku mɛt thïn nyuɔth.

sourceString: Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
targetString: Thökde ku ace yen kor, jɔ̈k cɔ̈k kuat HCoV aye kuɛnynuɛny thɔɔc cɔ̈k të ye kek rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn.

sourceString: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
targetString: Ke  yï cïn guop kïït tuany wula kïït thii tuany aa ke cï ke tïŋ wën cï aliɛ̈k luaŋ kuat CoV, ku e të ye kek rɔ̈t  dam thïn kam kuat CoV ku aliɛ̈k.

sourceString: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
targetString: Acï tuöl lɔn ka aliɛk aa ŋiɛc dom kuat CoV raan guop alɔ̈ŋ thïn ku të yë guop lui.

sourceString: For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
targetString: Cïmen, të le yen kë jɔ̈ɔ̈r alɔŋ käk guop cɔl atuc aliɛ̈k ic ku e thuou cï kuat CoV dhuök piny.

sourceString: Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.
targetString: Tëdɛ̈t, kën nɛ̈k aliɛ̈k iic aye thany piny rin cɔl kën yen ɣääc käk  NKG2/CD94 ku abaŋ kor anyïköl kek cɔl acï thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ käk guop tueŋ ic.

sourceString: Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.
targetString: Ku keya, abaŋ të dït alɔŋ aliir wɛ̈i (ROS) ye yɔ̈k käk ye cam alɔŋ aliɛ̈k aalɛ̈u bï CoV thany piny ku alɛ̈u bï kuɛ̈n ben ke kuen jɔ̈ɔ̈r exoribonuclease, ku keya e akuɛ̈ny gam të ye köm lui la ic thuou të cï yen ɣäth län dɛ̈t guop.

sourceString: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
targetString: CoV dït thuou thïn aalɛ̈u bïk jɔk ke ye nuɛ̈t yen cï kek rɔ̈t nuet, ku e yen protin kuöt ic wula protin e lui bï dom.

sourceString: Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
targetString: Tuɛnytuɛny kuat HCoV kä diäk kä aa ke cï bɔ̈ path ruon thiärɔu cï jäl.

sourceString: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
targetString: Kuat CoV aace näk wula kïït tuany aa lïk lääi ɣɛ̈ɛ̈c ke gup cïmen aliɛ̈k ku thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l.

sourceString: They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
targetString: Aa rɔ̈t juak ke ril ke cïn ke ril kek cɔl a lui kë rɛ̈ɛ̈r kek ye guop.

sourceString: Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
targetString: Kën ala ic kë cï thiän yeŋɔ̈ kë ye län ɣɛ̈ɛ̈c tuany ye ke tïŋ ku yeŋɔ̈ kën tuany cɔl a dït kɔc iic.

sourceString: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.
targetString: Kïït kä e rin ye kek lui guop ic apɛi ku luɔi cytokine ku të ye guop ye dhuök nhom thïn, e yen të ye cuɛ̈ny riɛ̈k thïn.

sourceString: In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
targetString: Ku kë wääc, tën lääi cï kïït tuany ŋic thïn, të ye guop ye dhuök nhom thïn acï dhuk piny arak rɔu juɛ̈ŋ ic CoV.

sourceString: The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
targetString: Dhel lɛ̈u bï të ye guop lui thïn tek thok alɛ̈u bï naŋ kuɔny e yäp wäl SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
targetString: Të ye interferon këdäŋ dhuök thïn a ril apɛi aliɛ̈k iic.

sourceString: Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
targetString: Ku këya, të ye abaŋ I interferon gam thïn të puɔc SARS-CoV-2 jɔk kɔc iic alɛ̈u bï naŋ këpath.

sourceString: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
targetString: Ku kë mɛt thïn, luɔi ye kuat NLRP3 protin lui aliɛ̈k iic ace lui apath.

sourceString: By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
targetString: Ku rin wɛ̈tkën, juɛ̈ŋ rot NLRP3 inflammasome kek MCC950 aalɛ̈u bï piath elace COVID-19 ic.

sourceString: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
targetString: Kë wïc alɔŋ SARS-CoV-2 abuɔth tën a jɔk SARS-CoV ku MERS-CoV thïn.

sourceString: Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Beta-CoV alïïk a rɔm 95% nucleotide kek SARS-CoV  acï yɔ̈k, ku ala CoV-alïïk rɔm 96% nucleotide kek SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
targetString: Aŋääth ku lääi tɔ̈u thuök aacï kek yɔ̈k ke ɣɛ̈ɛ̈c käm thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ kek SARS-CoV, ku kën ɣɛ̈ɛ̈c ke ye kë rɛ̈ɛ̈r SARS-CoV-2 ye guop akïc tïŋ.

sourceString: Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kuat Beta-CoV pangolin ret ke lui SARS-CoV-2 acï yɔk, ku aye nyuɔth lɔn lɛ̈u pangolin köm ɣääc wula kuat beta-CoV pangolin ale kë lëu bï juak te ye guop lui thïn ku bï SARS-CoV-2 jäl bɛ̈n bei.

sourceString: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
targetString: Cɔk alɔn le yen kïït thiëc ŋuɔt ke ŋoot, acïn kën yen nyuɔth lɔn adë ka SARS-CoV-2 e raan yen aloi ye ke ŋic wula loi ke kuc.

sourceString: CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kuat CoV aacï dhuk nhial rin tuany SARS-CoV-2 cï jɔk kën.

sourceString: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
targetString: Kuën kuen kuat CoVs aliɛ̈k iic ku lääi kök dhiɛ̈ɛ̈th acï të ye ok muɣɛma lääi  tïŋ war ku lääi ye ke kuat HCoVs yɔ̈k thïn tekde piny ran guop.

sourceString: Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
targetString: Wɛ̈t yic kɔc dɔk nhïïm acï nyuɔth lɔn ka SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV ku SARS-CoV-2 ala te ye yɔ̈k alïïk guop ku aala kɔc gup dhɔ̈ɔ̈l kɔc rom ke kek.

sourceString: Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.
targetString: Rin cï yen yɔ̈k lɔn ka SARS-CoV a jɔ̈k rɔ̈m kam kɔc ku aŋääth thuök iic, thiök thok thuök tiɔp ku nääk aŋääth alɛ̈u bï tuɛny SARS cɔl ajäl.

sourceString: By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Ku rin wɛ̈t tööŋ, pangolin aa wïc bï kek nyai thuök tiɔp iic ku bï tek piny tuɛnytuɛny lääi gɛ̈l, ku rin kë cï yɔ̈k kuat dhiɛ̈nh kuat beta-CoV pangolin thääny thok ke SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
targetString: Ku këya, cɔk alɔn wula të ye SARS-CoV-2 tɛk piny thïn tën kɔc ke jäl tën pangolin ku kuat lääi kök dhiɛ̈th aŋuɔt aŋot ke bï jam ic aköl ciɛ̈n.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
targetString: Ku tëdɛ̈t, MERS-CoV acï rɛ̈ɛ̈r thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l baai gup kam bär kɔ̈u.

sourceString: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
targetString: Thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l aa kek ye luɔ̈i ke ye käŋ ɣääc ku aaye cuet aya, aala caŋ, biok ku nhiɛ̈mden aye kɔc lui.

sourceString: They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
targetString: Kek aacï rɔ̈t tɛk piny apɛi Middle East ku Afrika.

sourceString: It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Ku yen a ril ic bï thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l juar rin bï ke MERS-CoV gɛ̈l, cïmen ke cï looi tën lääi rɔɔr thuök China in ku bï SARS-CoV ku SARS-CoV-2 gɛ̈l.

sourceString: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.
targetString: Ku bï MERS gɛ̈l bï cï la tueŋ, anɔŋ dhɔ̈ɔ̈l puɔth wïc bï kek nyai ku bï wäl MERS-CoV thɔ̈rɔ̈ɔ̈l cak, ku mat ke iic kek dhɔ̈ɔ̈l bï tuɛnytuɛny kök gɛ̈l.

sourceString: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
targetString: Rin cïn të lɛ̈u bï ok käm kä cɔl a jäl ebën, kën yam alɛ̈u bï tuɛnytuɛny cɔl a ben jɔ̈.

sourceString: A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
targetString: Kuat CoV lääi juëc aa rɔ̈t göt lääi rɔɔr ic.

sourceString: Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
targetString: Ku kë loi thok, kuat bat CoV kek kuat tuɛnytuɛny lääi aa kiith iic.

sourceString: There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
targetString: Anɔŋ dhɔ̈ɔ̈l juëc lɛ̈u bï kuat CoV lääi rɔ̈t cak  ku nuɛ̈t kä rɔ̈t, ku e yen të cï kuat CoV yam bɛ̈n nhial thïn rɔ̈t guɔ tek piny ku/wula thuou kɔc ic aköl tueŋ.

sourceString: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
targetString: Cääm ye kɔc cam lääi rɔɔr gɛth kök pan China awïc bï puöl ku bï tuɛnytuɛny lääi kɔc dom dhuök piny.

sourceString: With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
targetString: Ku kek athɛ̈m SARS, MERS ku COVID-19, aguiɛr path ku t-dhɔ̈ɔ̈l bï ke gɛ̈l aa dhil täu nyiɛnden.

sourceString: In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
targetString: Ku yic adïl, käm juëc aacï rɛ̈ɛ̈r piny kam bär kɔ̈u.

sourceString: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
targetString: Aa rɛ̈ɛ̈r ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ken ye kek yɔ̈ thïn ɣet dhaman bï kek rɔ̈t tɛk piny.

sourceString: Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.
targetString: Cɔk alɔn le aliɛ̈k käk tuany cɔl aweer rot piny, dhɔ̈ɔ̈l lɛ̈u bï kɔc rɔ̈m kek aliɛ̈k  ku lääi rɔɔr kök alɛ̈u bï kuɔr nyin të cï kɔc piɔɔc ku bïk rɔ̈t aa mɛc wëi ke lɔm.

sourceString: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.
targetString: La tueŋ cɛɛth ye lääi dhiɛ̈th caath gup apath ku bï të ye kuat CoV ku të ye kek rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn tiɛt thïn, ka bï kuɔny cɔk ke path ku bï tek piny tuany jäl lɔŋ lääi le raan guop ku kë bï rot looi aköl ciɛ̈n.

sourceString: To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.
targetString: Ku bï thiök cɔ̈k, dhel lɛ̈u bï tuɛnytuɛny lääi tiɛt wei e ku bï kɔc rɔ̈t ya mɛc wei të den ye kek rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn kek käm lääi.

sourceString: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
targetString: Käk juëc alɔŋ käk ye nyuɔth lɔn ye SARS-CoV-2 tuɛny lääi aa ŋuɔt ke liu.

sourceString: First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
targetString: Tök, na lɛ̈u aliɛ̈k bïk köm SARS-CoV-2 ɣäth pangolin gup, ka path bï tïŋ ye dhaman yïndë ye aliɛ̈k ku pangolin tö rɔm.

sourceString: Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
targetString: Rɔu, të le yen ke ye aliɛ̈k looi tek piny tuany raan guop, ka të kɔc ɔ̈m thïn kek aliɛ̈k a dhil yɔ̈p bï ŋic.

sourceString: Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
targetString: Diäk, na ye län ye kek diäk yen ye köm rɛ̈ɛ̈r ye guop, ka të ye yen rɔ̈m thïn kek lääi kök agut kɔc, aliɛ̈k ku pangolin a dhil cɔ̈k ic apath.

sourceString: Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
targetString: Thökde, rin cï lääi dhiɛ̈th la iic lääi ye mac bai aalɛ̈u bïk gup naŋ SARS-CoV-2, kë cï caath ku kë cï yɔ̈k të ye yen dom a dhil looi.

sourceString: Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.
targetString: Të yɔ̈k yen ke ye alïïk, pangolin wula län dɛ̈t dhiɛ̈th, ka bï dhiɛl tiit lɔn ka SARS-CoV-2 wula käk a dhiɛ̈th köm thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ aabï kek tïŋ ke ye kek ye käm yɔ̈k thïn aköl ciɛ̈n.

sourceString: Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
targetString: Giɛ̈k cï looi kela tueŋ alɔŋ kën abï të ye SARS-CoV-2 jɔk thïn lääi gup tet ic apath, ku e muɣɛm të bï COVID-19 gɛ̈l thïn ku muökde kɔc gup.

sourceString: Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
targetString: Ku bïdhɔ̈ɔ̈l ye ke tuany COVID-19 tiɛ̈ŋ thïn waar ic "ye tak kela tuany" ku "cï yɔ̈k kela tuany" apath bï rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn.

sourceString: On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Aköl nïïn 6 pɛi Rɔu ruon 2020, akutda acï dhɔ̈ɔ̈l kɔc wɛ̈ɛ̈t gäät aɣer ku bï kek coronavirus 2019 tïŋ ku lui elac thïn (2019-nCoV) ku athɔ̈r kën acï kë cuk yɔ̈k nyuɔth ku acï kɔc lɛ̈k të bï tuany kën gɛ̈l pinynhom.

sourceString: However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Ku këya, coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) e tusny yam, lɛ̈k ku ŋiɛ̈c käŋ da ajuak rɔ̈t amäth tëcït të cï kɔc yäp wɛ̈l yen luɛl thïn ku kë cï göt alɔŋ wal, ku këya, dhɔ̈ɔ̈l yeke tuany tïŋ ku elac aaye ke waar amäth.

sourceString: In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People's Republic of China.
targetString: Athɔ̈r thiin kën ic, ok aacï ke ye raan tak alɔŋ dhɔ̈ɔ̈l kuan cuk ke guir dhuk nhom ku ok aacï dhel dɛ̈t yam yeke tuany tïŋ bɛ̈i nhial alɔŋ "tuany ye tak lɔn tɔ̈u yen thïn" ku "tuany cï yɔ̈k" tëcït kë cuk yɔ̈k yemɛ̈nɛ̈ dhɔ̈ɔ̈l yeke tuany tïŋ ku elace COVID-19 (gäät dhorɔu) cï akut pial guop pan China luɛl aɣer.

sourceString: In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Pɛi Thiärkurɔu 2019, tuany ruon 2019 coronavirus (2019-nCoV) acï rot looi, ku e yen cï cäk emɛ̈nɛ̈ ka ye cɔl coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) ku köm acï cak ka ye cɔl e tuany ye yɔ̈k wɛ̈i ic severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

sourceString: On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
targetString: Aköl nïïn 11 pɛi Diäk ruon 2020, WHO acï COVID-19 cɔl ye tuany.

sourceString: In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
targetString: Wɛ̈tden buk thɔ̈ɔ̈r kek tuany SARS-CoV, akutda acï athɔ̈r kɔc wɛ̈t guir ku acï täu webthaith Military Medical Research aköl nïïn 06 pɛi Rɔu ruon 2020.

sourceString: It has attracted a great attention since published.
targetString: Acï kɔc juëc tuut mɛ̈nɛ̈ tɛ̈u yen webthaid kɔ̈u.

sourceString: Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Muk nhom lɔn ka COVID-19 e tuany yam, lɛ̈k ku ŋiɛ̈c käŋ ajuak rot amäth tëcït të cï yen yɔ̈k thïn ku kë cï yɔ̈k panakïm; dhɔ̈ɔ̈l yeke tuany yɔ̈p ku elac aacï kek bɛr iic.

sourceString: For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People's Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.
targetString: Cïmen dhɔ̈ɔ̈l yeke tuany yɔ̈p ku elac alɔŋ COVID-19 cï akut lui alɔŋ pial guop kɔc pan China (https://www.nhc.gov.cn/), kam aköl nïïn 16 pɛi Tök ruon 2020 le aköl nïïn 3 pɛi Diäk ruon 2020, acï athɔ̈ɔ̈r cï göt kädhorɔu  gam ku të ye yen lui acï rot waar amäth.

sourceString: Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
targetString: Zhou et al. ala kë cï göt alɔŋ athɔ̈rda, acï të ye kɔc tiɛm thïn nyuɔth tëcït të cïk yɔ̈k yen alɔŋden panakïm.

sourceString: Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Luɔiden acï yiny yam juak thïn athɔ̈rda ic ku ale kë cï kek ok tuɔc thïn alɔŋ tuɛny pinynhom kën.

sourceString: We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
targetString: Ok aacï luɔiden pɛth cïk looi kuɔny cök ku aacuk lec.

sourceString: However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
targetString: Ku këya, luɔi kën awïc bï ben dhuök ic kë cït kë cï yɔ̈k alɔŋ dhɔ̈ɔ̈l yeke tuany yɔ̈k ku elac COVID-19 (abaŋ dhorɔu them) ku kë cï piac kuen.

sourceString: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:
targetString: Tëcït të cï gäät dhorɔu luɛ̈l yen (aköl nïïn 3 pɛi Diäk ruon 2020) ku bi tuany ŋic ku bï kuat anyiköl töŋ tuany nuet ic  kek käŋ kärɔu cï göt panakim të cïn ye anyïköl puɔth tuany cï yɔ̈k.

sourceString: Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).
targetString: Anyiköl tuany: (1) anyiköl la keny wula rɛ̈ɛ̈r gen Wuhan ku bɛ̈ɛ̈i thiäk kek yen, wula akut kɔc cï COVID-19 yɔ̈k thïn nïïn 14 kïc kïït tuany guɔ jɔk; (2) anyiköl cï raan röm kek raan cï luaŋ SARS-CoV-2 (kek nucleic acid cï them ku ala ic tuany); (3) anyiköl cï raan röm kek kɔc tuany juäi/la atuöc wula kïït tuany wɛ̈i iic gen Wuhan ku bɛ̈ɛ̈i thiääk kek yen, wula akut kɔc kök cï ke COVID-19 yɔ̈k thïn nïïn 14 kïc kïït tuany guɔ jɔk; (4) anyiköl röm ke akut tuɛnytuɛny cï kek yɔ̈k (>2 käŋ kärɔu kek juäi/atuöc ku/wula kek kïït tuɛny wɛ̈i iiccï rot looi wudhbuɔ̈ɔ̈ kä 2 ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n kor iic, cïmen bai, maktap, ɣɔ̈npiööc thukul le tueŋ).

sourceString: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.
targetString: Käk cï göt alɔŋ wal: (1) juäi/atuöc ku/wula kïït tuany wɛ̈i ic; (2) ku käk COVID-19; (3) piath riɛm ɣer, cï dhuk piny, wula dhuk piny lympocyte të puɔc tuany jɔk.

sourceString: Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.
targetString: Ku bï tuany cï tïŋ gam atɔ̈u tuany dɛk kɔc puöth ic kek köm töŋ wula yiith cï riɛm ke nyuɔth cïmen: (1) Athɛ̈m PCR alɔŋ SARS-CoV-2; (2) të ye köm lui thïn guop ke nyoth ke thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ke coronavirus; (3) ke IgM käk guop ku IgG käk SARS-CoV-2 athɛ̈m riɛm ic; wula awɛ̈r ic IgG käk lui guop SARS-CoV-2 cïn tuany le tuany, wula jɔ̈nrot kë wïc guop ic >4 alɔŋ kam ye kɔc ŋuɛ̈n.

sourceString: We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
targetString: Athɛ̈m PCR yic ayeku tïŋ alɔŋ nucleic acid ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n wɛ̈i wula riɛm cï nyai bï them ecï mat gäät rɔu ic (aköl nïïn 18 pɛi Tök ruon 2020) ku gäät diäk (aköl nïïn 22 pɛi Tök ruon 2020).

sourceString: The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.
targetString: Köm cï tïŋ riɛm ic ke ye thuou lac bëi acï mat kën ŋuan ic (aköl nïïn 27 pɛi Tök ruon 2020) ku dhïc (aköl nïïn 8 pɛi Rɔu ruon 2020) gäät; ku käk cï riɛm nyuɔth aacï ke mat gäät dhorɔu ic.

sourceString: These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.
targetString: Käk cï kek cök piny tëcït të cï kɔc yäp wɛ̈l lui thïn lɔn bï kɔc yäp nucleic acid wɛnh ye kɔc tïŋ gup, a gut käk cï ke nyai alɔŋ ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye kɔc ke wɛ̈i ku ala ic käk riɛm, kën käjuëc rɛ̈ɛ̈r guop ic nyuɔth,  ku e kuat kë wën wïc guop ic nyuɔth të wïc yen thïn.

sourceString: Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
targetString: Ku etën, ala käjuëc o täk nhïïm ku buk nyïïn tït kïït ku liu kïït kɔc tuany gup.

sourceString: Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
targetString: Ku këya, kë cï Zhou et al göt a dhil ben bɛɛr ic, rin cï kek kɔc ce kïït nyuɔth cɔl "ka cïn riɔc".

sourceString: The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
targetString: Kën käŋ mat iic awïc bï ben caath akïïm ku kuɛ̈n.

sourceString: To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
targetString: Ku ba thiök cök, aa ŋöth ku yïïth juëc abɔ̈ nhial ku ok aa kɔc kuen bïk ok lɛ̈k kë yekä tak.

sourceString: For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
targetString: Rin "tuany cï tïŋ" ku "tuany cï yɔ̈k", aaye ku lɛ̈k yïn ku bï tuany yɔ̈p cök ku thek kuat dhɔ̈ɔ̈l cï kek bɛ̈i bei gɛɛth ic.

sourceString: Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
targetString: Akutda abï dhɔ̈ɔ̈l kuan cuk göt ben bɛɛr iic ku bïk kɔc kony.

sourceString: Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
targetString: Bangladesh acï kɔc kä dhïc cï thou rin COVID-19 cal, ku ela nhial akölaköl.

sourceString: Yesterday, Bangladesh has confirmed five new deaths due to COVID-19 on the day.
targetString: Wäraköl, Bangladesh acï kɔc kä dhïc ben yɔ̈k ke cï thou COVID-19 aköl.

sourceString: This is the highest number of fatalities in a day due to the virus.
targetString: Kën e yen adat thuou rot looi akal tök rin köm.

sourceString: As of yesterday, Bangladesh's Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) reported the number of recorded infected cases included 114 active cases and 33 recovered cases who were staying home.
targetString: Cïmen awärköl, Thukul Bangladesh muk alɔŋ tuɛnytuɛny ku wal nhom Bangladesh's Institute of Epidomology, të ye tuany gɛ̈l thïn ku yɔ̈p wɛ̈l Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) aacï adat kxc cï luaŋ tuany cal aɣer agut ran 114 ŋot ke tɔ̈u ku ran 33 cï ŋuɛ̈n e tuany keke rɛ̈ɛ̈r baai.

sourceString: A total of 17 deaths have been recorded.
targetString: Adat ran 17 aacï göt ke kɔc cï thou.

sourceString: In an online news briefing, the director of IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, said the fatalities included four males and one female.
targetString: Wɛ̈l yam kɔc webthaid kɔ̈u, mudir kën IEDCR, Dr. Meerjady Sabrina Flora, acï luel kɔc cï thou iic ala iic rɔ̈ɔ̈r kä ŋuan ku tiɛŋ tök.

sourceString: According to Dr Meerjady, two cases were aged above 60, two between 51 and 60, and one 41-50 years old.
targetString: Tëcït të cï Dr. Meerjady luɛ̈l yen, kɔc kärɔu aa kɔc la ruon 60 le tueŋ, kɔc kärɔu atɔ̈u kam 51 le ruon 60, ku raan tök atɔ̈u kam ruon 41 le 50.

sourceString: She also said two of the victims were from Dhaka.
targetString: Acï luel aya lɔn kä kɔc kärɔu aa kɔc pan Dhaka.

sourceString: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11.
targetString: Manadhama lui käk pial guop pinynhom (WHO) acï COVID-19 cal keye tuɛny pinynhom pɛi Diäk aköl nïïn 11.

sourceString: A hospital official told Anadolu Agency, a local news outlet, that one of the deceased was Jalal Saifur Rahman, a director of Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, who was cared for at the Kuwait Maitree Hospital.
targetString: Aköl panakïm ŋic lɛ̈l Akut Anadolu, alɔŋ ye wɛ̈l bai cal thi, ela raan töŋ kam kɔc cï thou e Jalal Saifur Rahman, mudir ke;n Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, ku ecï tääc panakim Maitree.

sourceString: On Saturday, in an online video announcement, Bangladeshi Road Transport and Bridges Minister Obaidul Quader said public transport would be shut down for longer than initially planned, until this coming Saturday.
targetString: Aköl Thibit, kë cï cal video webthaith ic, Wudhir kën Dhɔ̈l ɣäc ku kɛ̈ɛ̈t wïïr Obaidul Quader ecï luel lɔn ka kä ye kɔc ke cath aabï thiök piny dhaman bär kɔ̈u ku abï dhaman cï guir wan, ɣet aköl Thibit bï bën.

sourceString: This public transport shutdown had initially started on March 26 and was planned to end on Saturday, April 4.
targetString: Thiök cï kä ye kɔc ke cath thiök ecï jɔk pɛi Diäk aköl nïïn 26 ku ecï guir bï thök aköl Thibit, pɛi Ŋuan aköl nïïn 4.

sourceString: Transport of essential goods -- medical, fuel and food -- was still allowed.
targetString: Cäth käk muɣem --wal, jath ku mïïth --ecï puöl.

sourceString: The first recorded incidents of COVID-19 infection in Bangladesh were on March 8, in two people who returned from Italy and also the wife of one of them.
targetString: Kë töŋ cï kaŋ yɔ̈k alɔŋ COVID-19 pan Bangladesh eye pɛi Diäk aköl nïïn 8, kɔc kärɔu ke dhuk ciɛ̈n pan Italy ku jal a tiŋ raan tök kam ken.

sourceString: As of March 19, these three had already recovered.
targetString: Ku na ye pɛi Diäk aköl nïïn 19, ka kɔc kä diäk aacï ŋuɛ̈n.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 surpasses one million infections worldwide
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 acï ran malion tök wan ke cï luaŋ pinynhom ebën.

sourceString: On Thursday, the total number of cases of the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infections surpassed one million worldwide, Johns Hopkins University data indicated.
targetString: Aköl Ŋuan, adat kɔc ke cï luaŋ SARS-CoV-2 acï malion tök wan pinynhom, acï kë cï Jama Johns Hopkins göt nyuɔth.

sourceString: At least 52 thousand deaths were linked to COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
targetString: Tëcït tën ran alïp 52 aacï kek thääny COVID-19 bï ya yen cï kek nök, tuɛny cï coronavirus bɛ̈i.

sourceString: The milestone came the same day Malawi confirmed its first coronavirus infections and Zambia had its first coronavirus-related death.
targetString: Ku këdït dä ecï rot ben looi aköl töŋ yɔ̈k Malawi raanden cï luaŋ coronavirus ku Zambia ecï raan tök thou thïn thääny thok kek coronavirus.

sourceString: North Korea claimed, as of Thursday, it was one of the few countries remaining free of coronavirus infections.
targetString: Ku ecï Korea alɔŋ tueŋ luel lɔn ye kek gen töŋ cï coronavirus pinynhom.

sourceString: By yesterday, the World Health Organization reported 1,051,635 confirmed cases, including 79,332 cases in the twenty four hours preceding 10 a.m. Central European Time (0800 UTC) on April 4.
targetString: Ku tëcït tën wäraköl, go Manadhama lui käk pial guop pinynhom ran 1,051,635 keye kɔc cï luaŋ, ku aala iic ran 79,332 cï luaŋ akäl tök thäu 10 ariɛl ic thäu pan Ɣurup (0800 UTC) pɛi Ŋuan aköl nïïn 4.

sourceString: In the United States, over 244 thousand coronavirus cases were recorded, linking to at least 5,900 deaths.
targetString: Pan United States, tëcït tën ran alïp 244 cï luaŋ coronavirus aake cï cal, ku tëcït tën ran 5,900 ke cï thou.

sourceString: CBS News reported, citing Johns Hopkins University data, there were over 1,000 US deaths on Wednesday caused by coronavirus infections.
targetString: Acï CBS kën wɛ̈l yam cal aɣer luel, ku eke cï Jama Johns Hopkins göt yen acï ber ic, ela tëcït tën ran 1,000 le tueŋ cï thou pan US aköl Ŋuan ku e tuany coronavirus.

sourceString: Around the world, countries announced stricter measures to inhibit the disease from spreading.
targetString: Pinynhom, gɛɛth acï dhɔ̈ɔ̈l bï kek tuany gɛ̈l cal.

sourceString: On Thursday, Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, extended the city lockdown to May 1.
targetString: Aköl Dhïc, Sergei Sobyanin, bɛ̈ny geu kën Moscow, aci; bai thiöök piny bï ciɛ̈n kë lui ɣet aköl nïïn 1 pɛi Dhïc.

sourceString: Nationally, President Vladimir Putin declared Russians would continue to be paid without going to work until April 30.
targetString: Bai nhom ebën, Muorŋaknhom Vladimir Putin acï lɔn kɔc lui pan Russia aabï la tueŋ ke döm wɛuken ke cï la luɔi ic ɣet pɛi Ŋuan aköl nïïn 30.

sourceString: The parliament of Portugal voted to extend the national state of emergency by 15 days; the vote passed with 215 votes in favor, ten abstentions, and one vote against.
targetString: Ɣɔ̈n lööŋ pan Portugal aacï löŋ thany ic by bai thiök nïïn 15; kɔc cï cuɛt bi kën looi aa 215, ran thiär aa kïc bën, ku ran tök yen acï jai.

sourceString: Saudi Arabia extended curfews in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina to last the entire day; previously, the curfew was only in effect between 3 p.m. and 6 a.m.
targetString: Saudi Arabic acï cäth kum wäkɔ̈u gɛth dhɛ̈ŋ yï Mecca ku Medina ku bï ya aköl yen ye thöl; thɛ̈ɛ̈r wär, kuom cï cäth kum e ye jɔ̈k kam thäu 3 thɛ̈i ku thäu 6 arial ic.

sourceString: Thailand planned to implement a curfew between 10 p.m. and 4 a.m.
targetString: Acï Thailand tak bï ciɛ̈n raan ben cath thäu 10 wäkɔ̈u le thäu 4 bɛ̈kpiny.

sourceString: The governor of Ohio, Mike DeWine, announced the state had extended its stay-at-home order until May 1.
targetString: Acï Governormkën Ohio, Mike DeWine, cal lɔn cï kek yen tak bi rɛ̈ɛ̈r bai cuot ɣet pɛi Dhïc aköl nïïn 1.

sourceString: Stores in Australia lower toilet paper limits per transaction
targetString: Ɣɔ̈ɔ̈t ye kɔc tɔ̈ɔ̈u thïn acï wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wun dhuök piny të ɣɔ̈ɔ̈c yen.

sourceString: On Sunday and Saturday evening, Australian store chains Woolworths and Coles lowered their purchase restrictions on toilet paper to two and one package per transaction in all stores on national level, respectively.
targetString: Aköle Läät ku aköl Thibit thɛ̈i, Ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye kɔc tɔ̈ɔ̈u thïn Australia Woolworths ku Coles aake cï wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wun dhuök piny ku bïk ya rɔu ku jɔl töŋ la ic kë thïï nyɔt të ɣɔ̈c raan ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n tɔ̈ɔ̈u iic gɛu ic ebën, ke thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ.

sourceString: ALDI also introduced a one-pack limit, on Monday.
targetString: ALDI acï ɣɔɔc wei daska tök cal, aköl rɔu.

sourceString: These limitations were posted as messages on the checkouts, and on the chains' Facebook pages.
targetString: Käk cï kek dhuök piny aake cï piät ɣɔɔn ye kɔc öm thïn, ku Facebook.

sourceString: Buyers were reportedly stocking up due to fears of COVID-19 in case people need to self-isolate.
targetString: Kɔc juëc aa ke ɣɔɔc rin riɔ̈c kek COVID-19 tɛkdë bï kɔc ke thook lel.

sourceString: On Wednesday, Woolworths also limited toilet paper purchases for home delivery to one pack per order.
targetString: Aköl ŋuan, Woolworths acï wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wun dhuök piny bï ya daska tök yen e raan ɣɔɔc bï bɛ̈i tën yen baai.

sourceString: These changes followed the previous four-pack per transaction restriction introduced by Woolworths and Coles on March 4 and 5 respectively.
targetString: Käk cï rɔ̈t waar kä aa buɔth wargak kä ŋuan ke cï ke puöl bi ya kek ye raan ɣɔɔc rin cï käŋ looi bïk iic riɛl ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ɣɔɔc Woolworths ku Cole aköl nïïn 4 ku aköl nïïn 5 pɛi Diäk ke thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ.

sourceString: Coles, in its March 8 media release, reported that with the four-pack restriction in place, "many stores are still selling out within an hour of delivery", and called the demand "unprecedented", while ALDI, in a Facebook post on Tuesday, called it "unexpected".
targetString: Coles, jamden pɛi Diäk ic aköl nïïn 8, acï luel lɔn ka dhukpiny bï ya daska käŋuan kek ye raan ɣɔɔc aŋot nyiɛnde, "Ɣɔ̈ɔ̈t juëc ye kɔc tɔ̈ɔ̈u thïn aa ŋuɔt ke ye ɣɔɔc wei thäu ic ye kek käŋ ɣäth bɛ̈ɛ̈i iic", ku kë wïc aacïk cɔl "kë loi thok", ku acï ALDI cɔl "kïc tïŋ".

sourceString: Sales went up in a "sharp increase" last week, according to a Woolworths spokesperson.
targetString: Käŋ aacï la nhial "ajuɛ̈k rac" wudhbuɔ cï jäl, tëcït të cï raan jam alɔŋ Woolworth luɛ̈l yen.

sourceString: Costco's store in Canberra also limited the allowed amount to two packs last week.
targetString: Ɣɔ̈n tɔ̈ɔ̈u Costco pan Canbera acï daska kärɔu puöl bï ya kek ye raan ɣɔɔc wudhbuɔ cï jäl.

sourceString: To further alleviate the shortage, Coles ordered bigger packages from suppliers and increased delivery frequency, Woolworths ordered extra stock, while ALDI made stocks for a planned Wednesday special available early.
targetString: Ku bï liu käŋ nyuɔth, Coles acï daskaa dït cɔl bï ya kek ye kɔc ke muɔc bithdha bɛ̈i ku juak kä kam ye kek käŋ tɛk bɛ̈ɛ̈i ic, Woolworths acï ɣɔ̈t muɔc ic käjuëc, ku ALDI acï ɣɔɔc in aköl Ŋuan cï guir tɔ̈u bï lac guɔ rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn.

sourceString: Russell Zimmerman, executive director of the Australian Retailers Association, said that retailers try to raise stock, but local council restrictions on the timing of truck-deliveries make it hard.
targetString: Russell Zimmerman, bëny wat akut kɔc kom piny Australia Australian Retailers Association, acï luel lɔn cï kɔc kom piny yen them bïk käjuëc ɣɔɔc, ku rin lööŋ cï bäny täu e dhaman bï thurumbil käŋ bɛ̈i cɔl a ril ic.

sourceString: He expects rising production costs, as suppliers try to meet demand, and fewer specials.
targetString: Aye ŋööth lɔn bï käŋ rɔ̈t juak, ke ye kɔc käŋ bɛ̈i them bï käk wïc lɛ̈u, ku aa këlik muɣem.

sourceString: On Tuesday, ALDI announced that following the early release of stock, some stores can't run the Wednesday special.
targetString: Aköl Diäk, acï ALDI cal rin cï käŋ gäu, ɣɔɔn ɣɔɔc kök aacï bï lui aköl Ŋuan.

sourceString: In a News.com.au report, Dr Gary Mortimer, retail expert from Queensland University of Technology, said the stores fill the stock every night.
targetString: Wɛ̈l yam News.com.au iic, Dr. Gary Mortimer, raan ŋic kom piny apath Jama Queensland Teknologia, acï luel lɔn ka ɣɔ̈ɔ̈t tɔ̈ɔ̈u aa käŋ tɔ̈u thëi thok ebën.

sourceString: He remarked toilet paper is a bulky item, leading to low quantity of stocks in numbers, and, when sold out, leaves vast shelf spaces empty, hardening the feeling of a shortage.
targetString: Acï lɔn ka wargak ye kɔc ke thäär e këdït, ku e yen cï käŋ cɔl a dhuk piny, ku na cï ke ɣaac wëi, ka piny abaŋ dït adöŋ ke rɛ̈ɛ̈r ic, ku e liu käŋ cɔl a ril ic.

sourceString: Coles and Woolworths have a view [that] if there was plenty of stuff on the shelf, if product like toilet rolls and sanitiser could be [bought] and are there in quantities, you would probably minimise the panic said Russell Zimmerman per ABC News.
targetString: Coles ku Woolworth ala ke ye kä tak [lɔn] na la käjuëc ke tɔ̈u, ku na kä cït wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wun ku miök ye käm nök kɔc cïn [bɛ̈i] ku aa rɛ̈ɛ̈r thïn ke juëc, ka riɔ̈c alɛ̈u be ic tek acï Russell Zimmerman alɔŋ wɛ̈lyam ABC.

sourceString: Recycled toilet paper producer Who Gives a Crap said on last Wednesday they'd run out of stock.
targetString: Raan wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wun dhuök iic cï käŋ gam acï luel aköl Ŋuan  cï jäl lɔn bï käŋ liu tën kek.

sourceString: Kimberly-Clark, which makes Kleenex Toilet Tissue, and Solaris Paper which makes Sorbent, emphasized they were working 24/7 to maintain the supply, according to the News.com.au report.
targetString: Kimberly-Clark, raan lui wargak Kleenex ye kɔc ke thää wuny, ku Solari Paper lui Sorbent, aacik luel kek aa lui thäu 24/7 ku bïk käŋ ya bɛ̈i tën kɔc, tëcït të cï News.com.au yen luɛl thïn.

sourceString: Domain.com, a real estate site, reported some property sellers offering free toilet paper to the first bidder on auctions in Melbourne, when fewer auctions were held because of buyers having time off on the long weekend of Labour Day.
targetString: Domain.com, alɔŋ hɛla, acï luel lɔn ka kɔc abɛk käŋ ɣaac wei aa raan tueŋ ɣɔc thuŋ Melbourne tën kek yiɛ̈k wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wun ke cïn ke thiëc yen, të cï thuök thii nyɔt lui rin cï kɔc ɣɔɔc la lɔ̈ŋ yan aköl luɔi.

sourceString: The Thursday edition of NT News, a daily printed in Darwin, included an eight-page insert meant to be cut up and used as toilet paper.
targetString: Gäät aköl Dhïc wɛ̈lyam NT, ye ciɛr aɣer Darwin ic akölaköl, ci apääm bɛ̈t mat thïn wɛ̈tde ic alɛ̈u bï tem ku lui bï kɔc ke thäär ŋiny.

sourceString: The stores were originally reluctant to impose restrictions, according to a report from ABC Australia on March 3 in which they said they had no plans to introduce restrictions on the purchases.
targetString: Ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n tɔ̈ɔ̈u aa kïc kɔc mäc lööŋ, tëcït të cï ABC Australia luɛ̈l yen pɛi Diäk aköl nïïn 3 të cï ke yen luel thïn lɔn aacïk wïc bïk kɔc gɛ̈l käk wïc kä bïk ke ɣɔɔc.

sourceString: Russell Zimmerman added that other products are also in high demand, including masks, sanitiser, dried goods, handwash and flour.
targetString: Acï Russell Zimmerman luel aya lɔn ka kä kök ye ɣaac wei aa wïc kek ay, ku aala iic alanh ye kɔc ke thook ku wum kum, miök käm nök, bithdha cï riɛl, käk ye kɔc ke cïn lɔk ku abïk.

sourceString: Similarly, outside of Australia, on Sunday evening online British supermarket Ocado was observed limiting purchases of Andres toilet paper to two 12-roll packs.
targetString: Ke thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ, Australia aɣer, aköl läät thëi ka thuŋ ɣɔɔc wei webthaid ic cɔl Britsh supermarket Ocado ecï tïŋ ke dhuk ɣɔɔc Andres wargak ye kɔc ke thäär wuny bï daska la ic 12 yen ye ran ɣɔɔc.

sourceString: World Health Organization declares COVID-19 pandemic
targetString: Akutnhon de pialde gup , aci tuany ye cɔl COVID-19 caal ke ye tuany de pinynhom ebën.

sourceString: On Wednesday, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19 — the disease caused by coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 — to be a pandemic.
targetString: Në kool de diäk në wiikic, go Akutnhom ë Pinynhom Mɛ̈t në Pial (APMP) luel wu Covid-19 aci bɛn caal ke ye tuany ye bɛi në kɔm cɔl korona SARS-CoV-2 ku ye tuany de piny nom eben.

sourceString: Although the word "pandemic" only refers to how widely a disease has spread, not how dangerous specific cases are, the WHO noted the need to drive governments to action:
targetString: Na cukku wɛ̈t ye cɔl "pandemic"ya luel në biakde lɔ bïï de ku ci riɛ̈c de,ke ka ci WHO luel wu ka kɔɔr bi naŋ ke looi akuma.

sourceString: All countries can still change the course of this pandemic.
targetString: Bɛɛi kedhia aleu bike ŋot ëke geer tau de ye tuany de pinynhom.

sourceString: If countries detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilize their people in the response, said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the Director-General of the WHO.
targetString: të cëne bɛɛi kɔk tuany them. Ku dhiɛc ke bany de gël de tuany mɛn ye cɔl Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus de APMP.

sourceString: We are deeply concerned both by the alarming levels of spread and severity and by the alarming levels of inaction.
targetString: Ku wɔ diɛr në gudhur ɣok ɣe tuany rɔt ku dit de ku jal ya cen  kë loi.

sourceString: According to Dr. Tom Frieden, formerly the director of the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the pandemic is "unprecedented."
targetString: Dr.Tom Frieden, bany thɛɛr de gël de tuanyë pan cɔl United States, acïn kë  thööŋke yen tuäny de pinynhom ëbën .

sourceString: He said, in remarks published by CNN in February, "other than influenza, no other respiratory virus has been tracked from emergence to continuous global spread."
targetString: Aci luel në CNN në pende Akɔ̈nythii, "aci dɛt wäär influenza, aci tuany  dɛt bi cit ye tuanyë  në pinynhom ebën".

sourceString: Ghebreyesus expressed a similar view, saying "we have never before seen a pandemic sparked by a coronavirus."
targetString: Ghebreyesus acï jam "wu wɔ kën tuany de pinynhom  cɔl ̈̈korona kan tiŋ në min aɣɔn."

sourceString: He continued, "and we have never before seen a pandemic that can be controlled at the same time."
targetString: Aci ŋoot ke luel "wu wɔ kën tuany de pinynhom  ye gël kan tïŋ."

sourceString: The new status as a pandemic follows the WHO's decision in January to declare the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern.
targetString: Kë jöt de  tuäny de pinynhom akuany kë ɣɔn ci APMP luel në pɛɛi Kön, wu tuanyë ëke de pinynhom ebën.

sourceString: The United States' National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease's director, Dr. Anthony Fauci, said of the outbreak, "bottom line, it's going to get worse."
targetString: Aci mɔny Amirika ye cɔl Dr.Anthony Fauci mɛn ye nyin rït në tuɛnytuɛny yeke wɔɔk pande United States' luel wu ë tuanyë abi rac apɛi dite.

sourceString: As of Thursday, Associated Press reported there were at least 126,000 cases of COVID-19 worldwide, resulting in over 4,600 deaths.
targetString: Në köl de ŋuan, go caal ke raan 126,000 ci COVID-19 dɔm në pinythok ëbën ku 4,600 ci thou.

sourceString: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic is an ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Tuany de 2019-20 de pinynom, ë tuany de pinynhom ëbën ye cɔl tuany de coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) wën ye bɛi në kɔm ye cɔl 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

sourceString: The outbreak was identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019, declared to be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 30 January 2020, and recognized as a pandemic on 11 March 2020.
targetString: Lɔ bïï de ye tuanyë ë gɔl rɔt pan cɔl Wuhan, në China në kön, 2019,cɔɔle bïï në Kön e nïn 30, 2020 ku gam ke ye pandemic në Kol e nïn 11, 2020.

sourceString: As of 10 April 2020, approximately 1.61 million cases of COVID-19 have been reported in 210 countries and territories, resulting in approximately 97,000 deaths.
targetString: Në̈ pɛɛi nïn 10 Akɔ̈nydït 2020, adet de 1.61 million  acï  yök ke tuany në COVID-19 në bɛɛi ke 210 yic ku 97,000 acï  thou.

sourceString: About 364,000 people have recovered.
targetString: Adet de 364,000 raan acï  pial ama ci dɛm.

sourceString: The case fatality rate has been estimated to be 4% in China, while globally ranging from 13.04% in Algeria to .08% in New Zealand.
targetString: Adet cï thou pan ye cɔl china aye thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ke ye 4%, ku 13.04% pan ye cɔl Algeria ku .08% pan ye cɔl New Zealand.

sourceString: Common symptoms include fever, cough and shortness of breath.
targetString: kït cï aye atuɔi,dɔl ku wëëi cekic.

sourceString: Complications may include pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
targetString: Kä yeke loi në guɔpic aye tuany de gɔi yɔ̈ɔ̈k ku bï  raan nhiac piɔu.

sourceString: The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days, but may range from two to fourteen days.
targetString: Thɛɛr ke dɔ̈m de ku nyuɔɔth de kït ë nïn ke dhic jɔt,akë tɔu alë bï nïn ke two ka thiëër ku ŋuan.

sourceString: There is no known vaccine or specific antiviral treatment.
targetString: Acïn cï wël gël wenë wël tënë ye töök.

sourceString: Primary treatment is symptomatic and supportive therapy.Recommended preventive measures include hand washing, covering one's mouth when coughing, maintaining distance from other people, and monitoring and self-isolation for people who suspect they are infected.
targetString: Töök  tuëŋe bï raan yën  ka konye,kuɛɛr de gël e bï raan yecin ya waak,bi raan yethok ya kum të ɣɔl yen,bï kɔc ya rëër ëke mec cic  ku bï raan rɔtya tɔu yetök  të yen rɔt yök cït  ke tuany.

sourceString: Authorities worldwide have responded by implementing travel restrictions, quarantines, curfews, workplace hazard controls, and facility closures.
targetString: Pinynhom ëben acï ekenë piŋ ku thök  caath thook,ku ye kɔc ye diiu tau në      ɣan ken,ku gël ɣan ke luɔi ku thök  kɔ̈k thook.

sourceString: The pandemic has led to severe global socioeconomic disruption, the postponement or cancellation of sporting, religious, political and cultural events, and widespread shortages of supplies exacerbated by panic buying.
targetString: Tuanyë ye pandemi,  acï thuuk de pinynhom riɔk, ku ka cï kura,kanitha,ku thlatha ca thök  thook ku jai ya liu de kä bike ɣac thuuk.

sourceString: Schools and universities have closed either on a nationwide or local basis in 193 countries, affecting approximately 99.4 percent  of the world's student population.
targetString: Thukuul acï thök  thook në dola yic ke 193,acï 99.4% de mïth ke thukuul pɛn gaar.

sourceString: Misinformation about the virus has spread online, and there have been incidents of xenophobia and discrimination against Chinese people, other people of East and Southeast Asian descent and appearance, and others from areas with significant virus cases.
targetString: Tuanyë acï kuɛi thiäl në cabaka nyin, ku atek thok acï  dït tënɔŋ kɔc ke  China,ku kɔc    kɔ̈k ke bɛɛi wën nɔŋic ë tuanyë cï  mɛn  de kɔc   East ku Southeast Asia.

sourceString: Due to reduced travel and closures of heavy industry, there has been a decrease in air pollution and carbon emissions.
targetString: Acan cï  caath ku cirkat thök thook,ke alir acï  yic lau në ka wën ë ye ɣokic.

sourceString: Health authorities in Wuhan, China (the capital of Hubei province) reported a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown cause on 31 December 2019, and an investigation was launched in early January 2020.
targetString: Akutnhiim ke gël de tuany në Wuhan, China (rɔŋ de Hubei) acï tuɛnytuɛny ke gɔiyɔɔk caal ë Ɣɔ̈r e nïn 31, 2019, ku kɔɔr den yic agɔl në akɔ̈mudïriɛ Kön 2020.

sourceString: The cases mostly had links to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market and so the virus is thought to have a zoonotic origin.
targetString: Tuany tuany juëc athɛɛny rɔt  të yënë ɣɔc në rɛɛc ye cɔl Seafood ku kenë ayenë ye thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ke ɣök tenɔŋ lɛi.

sourceString: The virus that caused the outbreak is known as SARS-CoV-2, a newly discovered virus closely related to bat coronaviruses, pangolin coronaviruses, and SARS-CoV.The earliest known person with symptoms was later discovered to have fallen ill on 1 December 2019, and that person did not have visible connections with the later wet market cluster.
targetString: Kɔ̈m ë bïi ye tuanyë  aye cɔl SARS-CoV-2, e kɔ̈m jöt ci rɔt caal ke käm ke korona  wën ee tɔu aliik guɔp, ku pangolin ku SARS-CoV. raan tueŋ ë kɔn ɣök ke tuany ayök në pɛɛi nïn 1,köl 2019 ku raan ë akën thiak kenë thuuk yene ɣök.

sourceString: Of the early cluster of cases reported in December 2019, two-thirds were found to have a link with the market.
targetString: Në tuany cike luel biɛ në köl 2019,rou në diakic aci yök ke ci thiaak ke thuuk.

sourceString: On 13 March 2020, an unverified report from the South China Morning Post suggested that a case traced back to 17 November 2019, in a 55-year-old from Hubei province, may have been the first.On 26 February 2020, the WHO reported that, as new cases reportedly declined in China but suddenly increased in Italy, Iran, and South Korea, the number of new cases outside China had exceeded the number of new cases within China for the first time.
targetString: Në pɛɛi nïn 13 Aköldit 2020, acï kɔc ke South China luel wu tuany tueŋ ayök në pɛi nïn 17 kön 2019,në raan nɔŋ ruun ke 55 years  guɔp raan de pan cɔl Hubei. Në pɛɛi nïn 26 Akɔ̈nythii  2020, aye akutnhom ye cɔl WHO luel wu cï tuany dhuk piny në China ku ci dhiit në Iran ku South Korea awar china.

sourceString: There may be substantial underreporting of cases, particularly among those with milder symptoms.
targetString: Alë bï tuany ya caal ëke liik në biak de kɔc kor ë tuany kek.

sourceString: By 26 February, relatively few cases had been reported among youths, with those 19 and under making up 2.4% of cases worldwide.The United Kingdom's chief scientific adviser, Patrick Vallance, estimated that 60% of the British population would need to become infected before effective herd immunity could be achieved.
targetString: Në pɛɛi nïn 26 Nyith, acïn tuɛnytuɛny juëc ke riinythii nɔŋ 19 cike caal, ke anɔŋ 2.4% në pinynhom.  Banyde pan cɔl United Kingdom, Patrick Vallance acï luel wu adet de 60% de British akɔɔr bï kan tuany ku jɔl guɔp kak ken yen ke tuany gël loi.

sourceString: Cases refers to the number of people who have been tested for COVID-19, and whose test has been confirmed positive according to official protocols.
targetString: Kɔc yekë luel wu ka ci tuäny aye kɔc ci ke them ku yöke ëke nɔŋ guɔp tuany ye cɔl COVID-19, ku ka cï gam tuäny.

sourceString: As of 23 March, no country had tested more than 3% of its population, and many countries have had official policies not to test those with only mild symptoms, such as Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, and Switzerland.
targetString: Në 23 Aköldit,aci pan cï adet waar 3% yök ke tuany,ku bɛɛi kɔk ci mɛn de Italy, Netherland,Spain ku Switzerland ëya aci kɔc nɔŋ kor ye them.

sourceString: A study published on 16 March found that in China, up to 23 January, an estimated 86% of COVID-19 infections had not been detected, and that these undocumented infections were the infection source for 79% of documented cases.
targetString: Akuënë nyïc ë gätë bec kë Kol e nïn 16 e yökë kënë pande Caina, agut cë lan e Kön nïn 23, 86% ë wuɔk de COVID-19 ë thööŋë kɔ̈u akënë ŋic, ku kekë wuɔɔk kënë ke yök bï ke gät piny aakek ëke tharë 79% de wuɔk cï gät piny.

sourceString: A statistical analysis published 30 March estimated that numbers of infections in Italy were considerably greater than the reported cases.
targetString: Aci luel ëya në bïldit 30 Aköldit, wu adet ci tuany pan ye cɔl Italy acï dit awar adet ci caal.

sourceString: The initial estimates of the basic reproduction number (R0) for COVID-19 were 1.4 to 2.4.
targetString: Aci luel wu dhɛ̈ɛ̈th de ye tuäny ye cɔl (R0) COVID-19 aye 1.4 agut cë 2.4.

sourceString: A study published by the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that it may be 5.7.
targetString: Aci luel në akutnhom de gël de tuany pande US wu ka alë  bi ya 5.7.

sourceString: Most people with COVID-19 recover.
targetString: Kɔc juëc nɔŋ COVID-19 acï pial.

sourceString: For those who do not, the time from development of symptoms to death has been between 6 and 41 days, with the most common being 14 days.
targetString: Tenɔŋ kɔc kën pial, thɛɛr ke döm de ku thɛɛr ke thou aye niin ke  6 agut ci nïn ke 41, ake tɔu ëya në nïn ke 14.

sourceString: As of 10 April 2020, approximately 97,000 deaths had been attributed to COVID-19.
targetString: Në pɛɛi nïn 10 Kɔ̈nydït 2020, adet de 97,000 acï bɛn thou në COVID-19.

sourceString: In China, as of 5 February about 80% of deaths were in those over 60, and 75% had pre-existing health conditions including cardiovascular diseases and diabetes.Official tallies of deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic generally refer to dead people who tested positive for COVID according to official protocols.
targetString: Në pɛɛi nin 5 Nyith, adet de 80% ci thou anɔŋ ruun ke 60 lë tueŋ ku 75% ake nɔŋ tuäny kɔk cï mɛn de tuäny de piɔu ku tuäny de thukar. Kɔc ci thou ëke cike them gup ku yök keek ëke tuäny ke ka kuen ëke nɛk COVID-19 kek aaye ke thuŋ kekë kɔc cï them ku yök COVID ë ke guup në të cït tën ye lööŋ ke bäny e luɛl thïn.

sourceString: The number of true fatalities from COVID-19 may be much higher, as it may not include people who die without testing - e.g. at home, in nursing homes, etc.
targetString: Cin de  kɔc cï COVID-19 ke nɔ̈k aci rɔt dhiit, ku kɔc ci thou baai ëke kenë ke them liu thin.

sourceString: Partial data from Italy found that the number of excess deaths during the pandemic exceeded the official COVID death tally by a factor of 4-5x.
targetString: Aye pan ye cɔl Italy luel wu adet cï thou awar adet ci caal ke nɛk COVID na 4 ka 5x.

sourceString: A spokeswoman for the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) acknowledged "We know that [the stated death toll] is an underestimation", a statement corroborated by anecdotal reports of undercounting in the U.S. Such underestimation often occurs in pandemics, such as the 2009 H1N1 swine flu epidemic.The first confirmed death was in Wuhan on 9 January 2020.
targetString: Tiŋ ë kaŋ luel në biɛ de (CDC)pan ye cɔl U.S, acï luel wu ë tuanyë akenë ŋëc thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ apiɛth. Wɛtë aci luel ëya akutnhom dɛt. Ke cit ekenë acï rɔt kan loi në run de 2009 ɣɔn cënë tuäny ye cɔl H1N1 Swine Flu.Tuany tueŋ ayök në Wuhan në pɛi në 9 Kön 2020.

sourceString: The first death outside mainland China occurred on 1 February in the Philippines, and the first death outside Asia was in France on 14 February.
targetString: Thon tueŋ ci rɔt loi ke ce China ë pɛi nïn 1 Akɔ̈nythii pan cɔl Pilippines, ku thon tueŋ ke ce Asia ë pan ye cɔl France në pɛɛi nïn 14 Akɔ̈nythii.

sourceString: By 28 February, outside mainland China, more than a dozen deaths each were recorded in Iran, South Korea, and Italy.
targetString: Në pɛɛi nïn 28  Akɔ̈nythii, në China lɔŋ bia , ke thou aci dit pan cɔl Iran, South Korea ku Italy ëya.

sourceString: By 13 March, more than forty countries and territories had reported deaths, on every continent except Antarctica.Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.
targetString: Ne pɛɛi nïn 13 Aköldit, bɛɛi baak thieerŋuan nom aci thou ke rɔt loi thin, pan ye cɔl Antarctica yënë ka ci pooth.  Kuɛɛr juëc a yene ka adet ci thou ŋic.

sourceString: These numbers vary by region and over time, and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak, and population characteristics such as age, sex, and overall health.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.
targetString: Adet kenë ee wuɔi në bɛɛi yic, ku ka tɔu ne them cine ke them, ku tau de panakim,  tök de tuany, ku thaar ë bi tuany ku adet de raan ebën.  Adet ci thou anɔŋ të ye yïcök ɣen. Ëya adet cï thou ye tɛ̈k  adet cï yök ke tuäny.

sourceString: Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 6.0% (97,039/1,617,204) as of 10 April 2020.
targetString: Aci John Hopkins University luel wu adet ci thou ku adet ci tuäny ë  6.0% (97,039/1,617,204) në Akɔ̈nydït nïn 10, 2020.

sourceString: The number varies by region.
targetString: Adet awuɔi në tau  de bɛɛi.

sourceString: In China, estimates for the death-to-case ratio decreased from 17.3% (for those with symptom onset 1–10 January 2020) to 0.7% (for those with symptom onset after 1 February 2020).Other measures include the case fatality rate (CFR), which reflects the percent of diagnosed people who die from a disease, and the infection fatality rate (IFR), which reflects the percent of infected (diagnosed and undiagnosed) who die from a disease.
targetString: Në china, adet ci thou ku adet cï tuany thuuk piny në 17.3% (kɔc ëke gɔl kït ke röth në 1-10 Kön, 2020) agut cï 0.7% (kɔc ëke gɔl ë kit ke röth në pɛi nïn 1 Nyith 2020) kuɛɛr kɔk aye yi (CFR), wën yënë adet (IFR) de kɔc tuäny cï thou them ku jal ya kɔc cï tuäny ku ka ŋoot ëke pïïr.

sourceString: These statistics are not timebound and follow a specific population from infection through case resolution.
targetString: Adet kenë ace këde pan töŋ ci tuäny  në biak de nyɛɛi de tuany.

sourceString: A number of academics have attempted to calculate these numbers for specific populations.
targetString: Acï bɛ̈ɛ̈i abun juëc them ku bïk adat kä yup ic kek akut kɔc cï ke kuany.

sourceString: The University of Oxford's Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine estimates that the infection fatality rate for the pandemic as a whole is between 0.1% and 0.39%.
targetString: Jama Oxford lui alɔŋ wal acï thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ic lɔn tɔ̈u rɛ̈ɛ̈c e tuany kam 0.1% ku 0.39%.

sourceString: The upper estimate of this range is consistent with the results from the first random testing for COVID-19 in Germany, and a statistical study analysing the impact of testing on CFR estimates.
targetString: Thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ tueŋ de ya adet kenë aloi pan ye cɔl Germany ɣɔn theme COVID-19 ku jal ya them ɣɔn loi në CFR.

sourceString: The WHO asserts that the pandemic can be controlled.
targetString: Aye WHO luel ë tuanyë alë bi gɛl wëëi.

sourceString: The peak and ultimate duration of the outbreak are uncertain and may differ by location.
targetString: Nïn ka run bi e tuanyë ke thöl akuc kek ku ka bï tɔu kenë piny.

sourceString: Maciej Boni of Penn State University stated, "Left unchecked, infectious outbreaks typically plateau and then start to decline when the disease runs out of available hosts.
targetString: Maciej Boni de Penn State University,  aci luel na pial wuya ke tuany abi dhuuk piny të cen jal në ke yen piir guɔp.

sourceString: But it's almost impossible to make any sensible projection right now about when that will be".
targetString: Aci rɔt bï lëu bi thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ë thaar benë  ye kenë rɔt loi".

sourceString: The Chinese government's senior medical adviser Zhong Nanshan argued that "it could be over by June" if all countries can be mobilized to follow the WHO's advice on measures to stop the spread of the virus.
targetString: Diktor de pan ye cɔl China, Zhong Nanshan, aye luel wu tuäny abï jal në Bilthii të cënë bɛɛi ëbën ɣe kë ye WHO luel loi acan bi tuany rɔt cë ɣök.

sourceString: On 17 March, Adam Kucharski of the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine stated that SARS-CoV-2 "is going to be circulating, potentially for a year or two".
targetString: Në pɛɛi nïn 17 Aköldit, Adam Kucharski pan ye cɔl London, aye luel wu SARS-CoV-2 "abï rɔt wiic në ruɔn wëne run ke rou".

sourceString: According to the Imperial College study led by Neil Ferguson, physical distancing and other measures will be required "until a vaccine becomes available (potentially 18 months or more)".
targetString: Në biak de raan ye cɔl Neil Ferguson, aye luel wu mec de yic ku ka juëc kɔk wën ke gel alɔɔr bike ya looi agut cï köl bene wal yök (pɛɛi ke 18).

sourceString: William Schaffner of Vanderbilt University stated, "I think it's unlikely that this coronavirus—because it's so readily transmissible—will disappear completely" and it "might turn into a seasonal disease, making a comeback every year".
targetString: William Schaffner de   Vanderbilt University aci jam wu tuänyë  alë jal abi liu ku ka lë bi lɔ thuuk cën ku ye dɔm në ruɔn thok ebën.

sourceString: The virulence of the comeback would depend on herd immunity and the extent of mutation.
targetString: Dhuuk cën de ye tuäny në raan gup ë  jal lui këne guɔp du.

sourceString: Symptoms of COVID-19 can be relatively non-specific and infected people may be asymptomatic.
targetString: Kit yeneke COVID-19 ŋic athɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ kenë kɔk ku yëne ka yene kɔc ci tuäny cën kit.

sourceString: The two most common symptoms are fever (88%) and dry cough (68%).
targetString: Kit dit ke rou aye atuɔl(88%) ku ɣɔl ken luɔ̈k(68%).

sourceString: Less common symptoms include fatigue, respiratory sputum production (phlegm), loss of the sense of smell, shortness of breath, muscle and joint pain, sore throat, headache, chills, vomiting, hemoptysis, diarrhea, or cyanosis.The WHO states that approximately one person in six becomes seriously ill and has difficulty breathing.
targetString: Kit ke tuanyë cï juëc aret aye dac dhaar, ɣɔl bë juai, wëëi cekic, riɛɛm de yuɔm ku riŋ, töök de rɔl, akuemnom, aŋɔ̈ɔ̈k,dɔl në riɛɛm,  ɣääc wëne bi raan ya maŋök. Akutnhomde WHO ë  jam wu raan tok në kɔc ke dhetem yic alë bi tuany ku ril wëëi yic.

sourceString: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) lists emergency symptoms as difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain or pressure, sudden confusion, difficulty waking, and bluish face or lips; immediate medical attention is advised if these symptoms are present.Further development of the disease can lead to severe pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, septic shock and death.
targetString: Akutnhom de gel de tuany (CDC)pan ye cɔl U.S. aci kit yene ke tuany ŋic luel;wëi rilic, töök de piɔ̈u, nhom tiɛɛt, jöt de rɔt rilic ku thok maŋök,  na ci kit yic riɛl ke töök akɔɔr bi loi panakim. Dit de tuany në guɔpic alë gɔiyɔɔk riɔk,  alë bi wëi ca rilic, kɔɔc de piɔ̈u ku thou.

sourceString: Some of those infected may be asymptomatic, with no clinical symptoms but with test results that confirm infection, so researchers have issued advice that those with close contact to confirmed infected people should be closely monitored and examined to rule out infection.
targetString: Kɔc ci tuany alëu bike kit ke tuany ce nyuuth kit tënë ke ye ŋic ke ci cɔk them ke tuany ëke në aci dïktor jam wu kɔc ci thiaak kene raan tuäny alë bike ya dot apiath ku them kek agoke tiŋ mɛn tɔu tuäny.

sourceString: Chinese estimates of the asymptomatic ratio range from few to 44%.
targetString: Aye Chinese luel wu adet ci 44% aa tuäny ku ka kën kit nyuɔɔth.

sourceString: The usual incubation period (the time between infection and symptom onset) ranges from one to 14 days; it is most commonly five days.As an example of uncertainty, the estimate of the fraction of people with COVID-19 who lost their sense of smell was initially 30% and later fell to 15%.
targetString: Thaar ë dɔm tuäny raan ku thaar ɣe nyuɔɔth de kit e köl tok agut ci nïn ke 14 jɔt; kë gak e  naŋ nïn ke dhic. Në biak de kak thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋe ke, adet de 30% ci tuäny në COVID-19 ace ŋöör apiath ku adet aci bɛn thuuk piny 15%.

sourceString: Some details about how the disease is spread are still being determined.
targetString: Kuɛɛr juëc kɔk wën yeneke tuänyë  wuɔɔk aŋoot ëke kɔɔr kek.

sourceString: The disease is believed to be primarily spread during close contact and by small droplets produced during coughing, sneezing, or talking; with close contact being within 1 to 2 metres (3 to 6 feet).
targetString: Tuänyë  aci gam ke ye rɔt wuɔɔk arët të cine kɔc yic thiɔk ku të cine thueithuei bɛn bei të ɣɔlnii; të ruined,të cëmëm yic thiɔk në gudhur de mitiir 1 agut cë 2 (akäth ke 3 agut cë 6).

sourceString: Studies have found that an uncovered coughing can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 metres (15 feet) to 8.2 metres (27 feet).
targetString: Aci yök ke yen na ɣɔl raan ke kën yethok kum ke thueithuei acath në mitiir ke 4.5(cok ke 15)ku 8.2(cök ke 27).

sourceString: Some have proposed that the virus may also be transmitted by small droplets that stay for more prolonged periods in the air, that may be generated during speech.Respiratory droplets may also be produced during breathing out, including when talking, though the virus is not generally airborne.
targetString: Aye kɔc kɔ̈k luel wu tuanyë aye wuɔɔk të nɔŋ yen thueithuei  cï bɛ̈n bei në raan thok lekë në aliiric të jɛ̈m ë raan. Thueithuei kë aye bɛ̈n bei të wëëi ë raan bië ku të jɛ̈më raan, acok ka mɛɛn ka cenë tuany da aliiric.

sourceString: The droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.
targetString: Thueithuei kë alë bïke tëk në yï thok ka yï wum lekë në gɔ̈iyɔ̈ɔ̈kic të wëëi ë raan thïn në raan tuany lɔ̈m.

sourceString: Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause respiratory secretions to be aerosolized and thus result in airborne spread.
