targetString: Na ɣɔn në pɛɛi nïn 16 Akoldït, go akutdhom de pialde de guɔp në piny thook ebën luel bi raan ebën them në COVID-19. Ku rin wïc yen bï kɔc them rin cï köm rot tɛk piny acï kɔc juëc cɔl alɔ bɛ̈ɛ̈i akïm tujäria pan U.S ɣɔ̈n ye kɔc them gup thïn, ku gɛm wɛ̈th ye kɔc them gup ku kimkol guöp cɔl alui aacï lïk.

sourceString: In March 2020 China reported problems with accuracy in their test kits.
targetString: Në Akoldït 2020, Go china caal ke käke thëm cie piath areetic.

sourceString: In the United States, the test kits developed by the CDC had "flaws;" the government then removed the bureaucratic barriers that had prevented private testing.Spain purchased test kits from Chinese firm  Shenzhen Bioeasy Biotechnology Co Ltd, but found that results were inaccurate.
targetString: Pan United States, wɛ̈ɛ̈th ye kɔc them gup cï CDC guir aa naŋ kë "jɔ̈ɔ̈r;" thïn ku akuma acï käk kɔc gɛ̈l bï kɔc cï them nyai thïn. Spain acï wɛ̈ɛ̈th ye kɔc them gup ɣɔɔc tënë cïrka Shenzhen Bioeasy Biotechnology Co. Ltd, ku acï yɔ̈k lɔn kä athɛ̈m cï loi yen akïc ya tëde.

sourceString: The firm explained that the incorrect results may be a result of a failure to collect samples or use the kits correctly.
targetString: Ku ka ci kɔc ke panakim bɛn juiir apieth bii ke lëk kɔc ye kɔc ye ke nyuoth keke tuany,  aye kɔc ken në keek them apiath.

sourceString: The Spanish ministry said it will withdraw the kits that returned incorrect results, and would replace them with a different testing kit provided by Shenzhen Bioeasy.80% of test kits the Czech Republic purchased from China gave wrong results.Slovakia purchased 1.2 million test kits from China which were found to be inaccurate.
targetString: Go kɔc ke  Spanish, jam ye bi ka kek ke them dak nhiim ciën në kë ci keek ye lui apieth, ku bï kak lui apiɛth bɛ̈i në Shenzhen Bioeasy. 80% de ye kakë cï Czech Republic ɣɔc tenɔŋ China acï piɛth. Slovakia acï  1.2 million ke them ɣɔc tenɔŋ China ku ka cï lui apiɛth.

sourceString: Prime Minister Matovič suggested these be dumped into the Danube.Ateş Kara of the Turkish Health Ministry said the test kits Turkey purchased from China had a "high error rate" and did not "put them into use."The UK purchased 3.5 million test kits from China but in early April 2020 announced these were not usable.
targetString: Go bany cɔl Motovič,  luel ye käkë ke themi, ɣɔn lɔ ke bɛi pande Turkey aci lui apieth në ke cie ke yic ye nyuɔth. Britania acë ɣɔ̈ɔ̈c käke thëm në 3.5 maliöön tënë China lakin thökë Akɔ̈nydït 2020 gorë caal lɔn cï bɛ kek lui.

sourceString: Testing, followed with quarantine of those who tested positive and tracing of those with whom the SARS-CoV-2 positive people had had contact, resulted in positive outcomes.
targetString: Ku kɔc lɔŋ guɔ̈p tuany cenë ke SARS-CoV-2 yök në ke guup aci bɛn ya mɛɛi në kɔc  ci guɔp  tuany ku tɛɛu keek tëde ke pɛɛc.

sourceString: Researchers working in the Italian town of Vò, the site of the first COVID-19 death in Italy, conducted two rounds of testing on the entire population of about 3,400 people, about ten days apart.
targetString: Ku raan lui në akutnhom de pialde yic pande italy ee bɛn lɔ pandɛ cɔl Vò,  ne ye kool tok ŋiyic, ku ye pan ɣe thou ë raan  thin në COVID-19. Adɛt de 3,400 acï them guɔp në nïn ke thiëër yic.

sourceString: About half the people testing positive had no symptoms, and all discovered cases were quarantined.
targetString: Ku në kɔc ci keek them guɔ̈p yic, go biakden yök ke tuany ku cï kë nyuoth tuany në gup ku kɔc ci guɔ̈p pial aci ke bɛn dhiac keke tou keek tëde ke pɛi.

sourceString: With travel to the commune restricted, this eliminated new infections completely.
targetString: Ku tenɔŋ kɔc ye cath në ɣɔl kɔk yic keke piac tuany abi keek ya dɔm.

sourceString: With aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, the 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Singapore has proceeded much more slowly than in other developed countries, but without extreme restrictions like forced closure of restaurants and retail establishments.
targetString: Në biak de kɔɔr, thök de caath, them, ku rëër tetök, 2020 koronavirus në Singapore acï loi apiɛth awar baai kɔ̈k ŋot ëke yïïk kek, ku caath de riɛ̈th ku thök de matam akenë tau.

sourceString: Many events have been cancelled, and Singapore did start advising residents to stay at home on 28 March, but schools reopened on time after holiday break on 23 March.
targetString: Ku ka juɛɛi kɔk aci keek bɛn teem kɔth në pɛi nïn 28 Akoldït  ku Singapore aci kɔc bɛn ŋɔl në jëëm bi kɔc ya tɔu baai.  Ku bïï cen raan  cäth në pɛi  nïn 23 Akoldït.

sourceString: Several other countries have also managed the pandemic with aggressive contact tracing, inbound travel restrictions, testing, and quarantining, but with less aggressive lock-downs, such as Iceland and South Korea.
targetString: Bɛ̈i juëc kɔ̈k acï tuany bɛ̈n gël apɛi në bɔ̈ɔ̈th ë cök kɔc cë röt aagɔt kekë kɔc tuany, pɛ̈ɛ̈n ë cäth aalɔŋthïn, athɛ̈m, ku lɛ̈llɛ̈l thok, ku baai akïc guɔ thiök piny apɛi bï rɛ̈ɛ̈c këya, cïmen Iceland ku South Korea.

sourceString: A statistical study has found that countries that have tested more, relative to the number of deaths, have much lower case fatality rates, probably because these countries are better able to detect those with only mild or no symptoms.
targetString: Acï akuën cï looi  yɔ̈k lɔn ka gɛth cï kɔc juëc them, thiäk thook kek kɔc cï thou, anaŋ thuou kor ic, ku e rin cï gɛth ye them ku bïk kɔc la kïït thii tuany wula kɔc cïn kïït tuany lac yɔ̈k.

sourceString: WHO recommends that countries that do not have testing capacity and national laboratories with limited experience on COVID-19 send their first five positives and the first ten negative COVID-19 samples to one of the 16 WHO reference laboratories for confirmatory testing.
targetString: Aye APMP luel bɛ̈i cën nyïc tënë thëm ku ɣän ke ke thëm në baŋde COVID-19 bïk ŋuëkthii ke kɔc tueeŋ kɛn tuany ke dhïc aatuɔc ku kɔc kɛn tueeŋ cï tuany në COVID-19 tënë ɣöt ke thëm cï ke gam ka 16 në baŋde APMP agorë deet në thëm.

sourceString: Out of the 16 reference laboratories, 7 are in Asia, 5 in Europe, 2 in Africa, 1 in North America and 1 in Australia.
targetString: Ku në ɣöt ke kaciip ke 16 yic, 7 në Asia, 5 në Europe, 2 në Africa, 1 në North Amerika ku 1 në Australia.

sourceString: In the following chart, the column “Positive as % of tests” is influenced by the country's testing policy.
targetString: Ku në yekene yic,  go cin de kɔc tuany ya %   ci tan ci në kɔc kek baai ye luel.

sourceString: A country that only tests people admitted to hospitals will have a higher positive as % of tests than a country that tests all citizens, whether or not they are showing symptoms, other things being equal.
targetString: Ku gen kɔc cï ket tääc pan akïm e kɔc juëc cï luaŋ yɔ̈k tën gen cï kacke ebën them, cɔk alɔn le yen kïït wula cïn kïït tuany nyuɔth, ku kä kök ebën aa thöŋ.

sourceString: Hand washing (or handwashing), also known as hand hygiene, is the act of cleaning one's hands for the purpose of removing soil, grease, microorganisms, or other unwanted substances.
targetString: Lɔ̈k cin (wula lɔ̈k cin), ŋic ke ye aguiɛr cin, e wɛ̈t bï raan ye cin lɔɔk ku bï liɛt, cääm, käm ce tïŋ kɔc nyïïn wula käm kök cï kek wïc nyai kɔc cin.

sourceString: Hand washing with soap consistently at certain "critical moments" during the day prevents the spread of many diseases, for example diarrhoea and cholera, which are transmitted through fecal–oral route.
targetString: Ku wɛk yene kɔc ke cïïn waak në athabun yen në kä kɔɔr bi ya looi bɛn tuany gel cin mɛn de tuany cɔl Cholera.

sourceString: People can also become infected with respiratory diseases such as influenza or the common cold, for example, if they do not wash their hands before touching their eyes, nose, or mouth (i.e., mucous membranes).
targetString: Ku kɔc aleu bïkë tuany në tuany de piɔu të ci keke cin në wak apieth ku jakke nyin në cin nɔŋic wathak.

sourceString: The five critical moments during the day where washing hands with soap is important include: before and after defecation, after cleaning a child's bottom or changing nappies, before feeding a child, before eating and before and after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
targetString: Ku käŋ ke dhiëc aköl bï lɔ̈ɔ̈k cin kek thabun ya këye raan looi ku ala ic: të kïc raan guɔ la pel ku të cï yen thök pel, të cï raan meth ŋiny thar wula cï yen meth waar thar bampas, të kïc yïn meth guɔ miɛ̈th thok, të yïn guɔ mïth ku të kïc yïn miɛ̈th guɔ guir ku të cï yïn miɛ̈th guir wula të lui yïn rïŋ, rɛ̈c thith wula mäc ajïïth.

sourceString: If water and soap are not available, hands can be cleaned with ash.The World Health Organization recommends washing hands:
targetString: Ku te liiu ee piu ku thabun, ke ka kɔɔr ba yi cin ya wak në ŋeth.

sourceString: Before, during, and after preparing food.
targetString: Te ŋoot yin, ama te yi ku te cï thookkë thatama te ŋot yi ke yin ken apaɛi ke thäär lɔɔm.

sourceString: Before and after caring for a sick person.
targetString: Ku te ŋoot yin ke yi ken raan tuany laar akim.

sourceString: After changing the diapers or cleaning up a child who has used the toilet.
targetString: Ku te ŋoot yïn ke yin ke meth wak guɔ̈p te ce lɔ pakana.

sourceString: After blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing.
targetString: Ku te ŋoot yin ke yin ke në wum thöny.

sourceString: After touching animal, animal feed, or animal waste.
targetString: Ku te ce yin laai ku lony.

sourceString: Medical hand hygiene refers to hygiene practices related to medical procedures.
targetString: Ku ke ye cɔl pialde guɔp ëë luoi be në raan roth ya tiit në tuany ago raan yen cin ya waak apieth ba ya col ke yin wak yïn  cin apieth.

sourceString: Hand washing before administering medicine or medical care can prevent or minimize the spread of disease.
targetString: Na ye col ke yin wak yin cin ke ka leu bi tuany gel wei.

sourceString: The main medical purpose of washing hands is to cleanse the hands of pathogens (bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease) and chemicals which can cause harm or diseases.
targetString: Ku keye kɔc ke cin lɔɔk we wɛ̈t ku bï käk kɔc luaŋ laak wei (bakteria, käm, wula kuat käm thii kök ce kek ye tïŋ kɔc nyïïn lɛ̈u bïk tuany bɛ̈i) ku kimkol lɛ̈u bïk kɔc luc wula bï tuɛnytuɛny bɛ̈i.

sourceString: This is especially important for people who handle food or work in the medical field, but also an important practice for the general public.
targetString: Ku ye kenë apieth areetic ke kɔc ye lui panakim ku kɔc ye thät baai ku thuk ëya bïï ke cin dhil ya wak apiath.

sourceString: Hand washing has many health benefits, including minimizing the spread of influenza, coronavirus, and other infectious diseases; preventing infectious causes of diarrhea; decreasing respiratory infections;
targetString: Ba yiï  cin wak anɔŋ ka juɛc ye keek kuny yin në biak de pialde guɔp, aci tuany ye cɔ dɔm kɔc areetic.

sourceString: and reducing infant mortality rate at home birth deliveries.
targetString: Ku ke lɔ bii de tuany tekic.

sourceString: A 2013 study showed that improved hand washing practices may lead to small improvements in the length growth in children under five years of age.
targetString: Anɔŋ piooc ee ci looi ɣɔn në 2013, yë piööci aci kɔc kuny;  mënë bi kɔc ke cin ya wak.

sourceString: In developing countries, childhood mortality rates related to respiratory and diarrheal diseases can be reduced by introducing simple behavioral changes, such as hand washing with soap.
targetString: Ku në bɛɛi wel ci piɔy, ke tuɛnytuɛny ci mɛn de yi ɣɔl ake ye ke gel në wɛɛkde cin: ba yi cin ya wak në thabun.

sourceString: This simple action can reduce the rate of mortality from these diseases by almost 50%.
targetString: Ku kekakë  kedhia aye  kä ye në ke tuany cɔ kɔɔci në  gël në gudhur de 50%.

sourceString: Interventions that promote hand washing can reduce diarrhoea episodes by about a third, and this is comparable to providing clean water in low income areas.
targetString: Ku ka wel ye kɔc pioc ebën bi kɔc ke cin ya wak aa ye tuany gel ci mɛnde yäc ( yithaan ).

sourceString: 48% of reductions in diarrhoea episodes can be associated with hand washing with soap.Hand washing with soap is the single most effective and inexpensive way to prevent diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI), as automatic behavior performed in homes, schools, and communities worldwide.
targetString: Ku yithan alëu bi gel në gudhur de 48%, ba yin cin ya wak apieth në piu ku thabun e yene töŋ lui kuka rakïth e yäc gël ku jɔla wuɔɔk dït rilic tënë wëëï (WDW), ku käkë ayen keek looi në thukulic ku në bɛ̈ɛ̈i yic  ku pinynhom ebën.

sourceString: Pneumonia, a major ARI, is the number one cause of mortality among children under five years old, taking the lives of an estimated 1.8 million children per year.
targetString: Tuany aliir në piöuic, kë ye yene WDW, kë ke tueŋ në bi menh de ruunke dhïc nɔk, nɛ̈ken mïth ke 1.8 maliöön në ruön thok.

sourceString: Diarrhea and pneumonia together account for almost 3.5 million child deaths annually.
targetString: Ku yithan aleu bi ke cië miithke 3.5 million nɔk në döör tok abac.

sourceString: According to UNICEF, turning hand washing with soap before eating and after using the toilet into an ingrained habit can save more lives than any single vaccine or medical intervention, cutting deaths from diarrhea by almost half and deaths from acute respiratory infections by one-quarter.
targetString: Tëcït të cï UNICEF luɛ̈l yen, të ye kɔc ke cin lɔɔk thabun të kïc raan guɔ cɛm ku të cï yïn ke loi bakana ic thɔ̈ɔ̈l ku loi këye kë ye loi akölköl alɛ̈u bï pïr kony tën lɔn bï wäl tök luɔi wula kuɔny akïm, tɛ̈m kɔ̈u thuou tën yäc keye abak ku thuou alɔŋ tuɛnytuɛny ye yɔ̈k wɛ̈ɛ̈i iic keye ye abaŋ thïïn kor.

sourceString: Hand washing is usually integrated together with other sanitation interventions as part of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) programmes.
targetString: Ba yi cin wak ake thɛɛr ëye kɔc looi ku ke biak de pialde guɔ̈p de raan në piiric cï mɛn cenë ye luel ne (WASH).

sourceString: Hand washing also protects against impetigo which is transmitted through direct physical contact.
targetString: Ku wɛɛkde cin aa kɔc gel në tuɛnytuɛny awel ye ke wɔɔk te thïc kɔc roth në kudual.

sourceString: A small detrimental effect of hand washing is that frequent hand washing can lead to skin damage due to drying of the skin.
targetString: Ku na cie yi cin në wak kek riir cin wei ku dhiɛc ke ye tuany mdɛ.

sourceString: A 2012 Danish study found that excessive hand washing can lead to an itchy, flaky skin condition known as hand eczema or hand dermatitis, which is especially common among health-care workers.
targetString: Na ɣɔn në run de 2012, ke piooc aci looi ago kɔc ke cin ya wak bi akuɔk kɔc ci ye dɔm.

sourceString: Too frequent hand washing is also seen as one of the symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
targetString: Acän ba ya col ke ye wak yin cin aye tok de ka pieth areetic në nyindhiɛ e kït de tuany ye cɔl (OCD).

sourceString: There are five critical times during the day where washing hands with soap is important to reduce fecal-oral transmission of disease: after using the bathroom (urination, defecation), after cleaning a child's bottom (changing nappies), before feeding a child, before eating and before/after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry.
targetString: Anɔŋ thɛr tou në koolic ke dhïc ku pieth bi kɔc ke cin ya wak (në thabun; na cɔ lɔ pakana ke yin wak yi cin në thabun) ku të cï meth wak ( ku të geer yin meth kɔu)

sourceString: Other occasions when correct handwashing technique should be practiced in order to prevent the transmission of disease include before and after treating a cut or wound; after sneezing, coughing, or blowing your nose; after touching animal waste or handling animals; and after touching garbage.
targetString: Ku kä kɔ̈k piɛth arëëtic bukku piööc bi kɔc ke cin dhil ya lɔɔk në dhël lajik na thabun në nyindhiɛ agorë lɔ thiëi bec de tuany gël nɔŋic kë yï këc guɔ ca tëm wälë tëtöök alacu; ɛ̈ thiïm, ɣɔl, wälë thony yi wum; të cï yïn wɛ̈r wɛŋ wula läi gɔt; ku të cï yïn thök jukjuk anyuɔn.

sourceString: In many countries, there is a low rate of hand washing with soap.
targetString: Në dolat juëc cic, wɛ̈k de cin në asabun acï dït.

sourceString: A study of hand washing in 54 countries in 2015 found that on average, 38.7% of households practiced hand washing with soap.A 2014 study showed that Saudi Arabia had the highest rate of 97 percent; the United States near the middle with 77 percent; and China with the lowest rate of 23 percent.Several behaviour change methodologies now exist to increase uptake of the behaviour of hand washing with soap at the critical times.Group hand washing for school children at set times of the day is one option in developing countries to engrain hand washing in children's behaviors.
targetString: Akuën ë nyïnyë lɔ̈kë cin në bɛ̈i ke 54 ic ë 2015 e yökë kënë atuoc, 38.7% ë bɛ̈i aaye lɔ̈kë cin në athabun pïööc. Akuën ë nyïc dë 2014 e nyuɔth lɔn nɔŋ Saudi Arabia adɛn dït ë juëŋë röt de 97 në buɔtic; Amërika mɛn thïök cɛlic kekë 77 në buɔtic; ku China kë cinë juëŋë röt tɔ̈ piiny kekë 23 në buɔtic. Kuɛr juëc ë gɛra de ciɛɛŋ ëmɛn atɔ̈ ë kë bë juak në löömde ciɛɛŋ ë lɔ̈kë cin në athabun e dhamɛn rilic kënë. Akuut de lɔ̈kë cin tënë mïth ke thukul në thää kaköl cï ke juir e töŋ ë lɔ̈ɔ̈c tɔ̈ në bɛ̈i yïk ic aci ciɛɛŋ dë lɔ̈kë cin kuɔth në mïth nhïïm.

sourceString: The "Essential Health Care Program" implemented by the Department of Education in the Philippines is an example of at scale action to promote children's health and education.
targetString: Ajuiɛɛr cï kɔc ke pan ye cɔl Philippines loi abï thukul de mïth ku pialden de guɔp ca ril.

sourceString: Deworming twice a year, supplemented with washing hands daily with soap, brushing teeth daily with fluoride, is at the core of this national program.
targetString: Ajuiɛɛr de ye akutnhom ëkë, bï raan wël de kɔ̈m ya dek na rou në ruɔ̈nic bï raan ye cin ya waak në nyindhie ku bï raan ye thok ya gɔ̈ɔ̈k miäkduur.

sourceString: It has also been successfully implemented in Indonesia.
targetString: Acï rɔt loi Pan ye cɔl Indonesia.

sourceString: Removal of microorganisms from skin is enhanced by the addition of soaps or detergents to water.
targetString: Nyɛɛi de kɔ̈m në raan guɔp aa asabun yenëke ye loi.

sourceString: The main action of soaps and detergents is to reduce barriers to solution, and increase solubility.
targetString: Kë ye thabun loi ë kɔm ku acuɔl nyaai në raan guɔp.

sourceString: Water alone is an inefficient skin cleanser because fats and proteins, which are components of organic soil, are not readily dissolved in water.
targetString: Pïu ke pɛi acï lë bïkë acuɔl nyaai në raan guɔp rin miök ku protin, ku aa kek abɛ̈k liɛt, ku aace lac mär pïu iic.

sourceString: Cleansing is, however, aided by a reasonable flow of water..
targetString: Pïu a ye acuɔl nyaai të juëc kek.

sourceString: Solid soap, because of its reusable nature, may hold bacteria acquired from previous uses.
targetString: Asabun alë bï käm cë nyaai në guɔpic të kenë ye ŋic loi.

sourceString: A small number of studies which have looked at the bacterial transfer from contaminated solid soap have concluded transfer is unlikely as the bacteria are rinsed off with the foam.
targetString: Anɔŋ kɔc kɔ̈k ë ye luel wu athabun acï kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria ë nyaai të ken yïn ye lɔ̈k apiɛth në piu.

sourceString: The CDC still states "liquid soap with hands-free controls for dispensing is preferable".
targetString: Acï akutnhom de CDC luel wu athabun cï liäp ë pïu yenë ka ril.

sourceString: Antibacterial soaps have been heavily promoted to a health-conscious public.
targetString: Athabun wën ë kɔm ye cɔl bacteria nɔ̈k yenë ka cï kɔc juëc gam.

sourceString: To date, there is no evidence that using recommended antiseptics or disinfectants selects for antibiotic-resistant organisms in nature.
targetString: A kënë luel wu asubun yenë piny ë ye kɔm cï tɔu arët në guɔpic nɔ̈k.

sourceString: However, antibacterial soaps contain common antibacterial agents such as triclosan, which has an extensive list of resistant strains of organisms.
targetString: Aa yen kë tɔ̈u, asubun dɛ̈t ë lui apiɛth kënë kɔ̈m cï ceŋ arëëtic në guɔpic.

sourceString: So, even if antibiotic resistant strains aren't selected for by antibacterial soaps, they might not be as effective as they are marketed to be.
targetString: Na cɔk naŋ käm cë dac thou në ye asubunë ke asubun kɔ̈k aye nɔ̈k.

sourceString: Besides the surfactant and skin-protecting agent, the sophisticated formulations may contain acids (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) as pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid and further skin conditioners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts).A comprehensive analysis from the University of Oregon School of Public Health indicated that plain soaps are as effective as consumer-grade anti-bacterial soaps containing triclosan in preventing illness and removing bacteria from the hands.
targetString: Në ye kenë yic, wɛl yenë tuany de dɛ̈ɛ̈l tök anɔŋic kë ye cɔl (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) ke ye PH dhuɔ̈k piny, ku benzoic acid. Acï kɔc Ke Jamiya de Orego wu asubun nyin is kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria nyaai apiɛth. Kë cï yɔ̈k ke cï jama Oregon abaŋ lui käk pial guöp bää caath acï yɔ̈k ka thabuun la ic triclosan tuany gɛ̈l ku nyɛi bakteria kɔc cin.

sourceString: Hot water that is comfortable for washing hands is not hot enough to kill bacteria.
targetString: Pïu tuuc acï lë bïkë kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria nɔk.

sourceString: Bacteria grow much faster at body temperature (37 °C).
targetString: Kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria ë dac dït të lir (37°C).

sourceString: However, warm, soapy water is more effective than cold, soapy water at removing natural oils which hold soils and bacteria.
targetString: Ku keya, pïu tuc, la iic thabun aa ŋuɛ̈n tën pïu lir, ku aala iic thabun ku aa miök liɛt muk kɔc cïn guɔ nyai kɔc cin ku jɔl aa käm.

sourceString: Contrary to popular belief however, scientific studies have shown that using warm water has no effect on reducing the microbial load on hands.
targetString: Acï kɔc cï piëi luel wu pïu tuuc acë kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria ë nɔ̈k të piny ë raan yecin.

sourceString: A hand sanitizer or hand antiseptic is a non-water-based hand hygiene agent.
targetString: Kë yenë kɔc ke cin weec acï në piu.

sourceString: In the late 1990s and early part of the 21st century, alcohol rub non-water-based hand hygiene agents (also known as alcohol-based hand rubs, antiseptic hand rubs, or hand sanitizers) began to gain popularity.
targetString: Në run de 1990s ku 21st century, yene ka gamë yen mɛn käk ke lɔ̈ɔ̈k de cin nɔŋic miau keke piɛth.

sourceString: Most are based on isopropyl alcohol or ethanol formulated together with a thickening agent such as Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) into a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin into a liquid, or foam for ease of use and to decrease the drying effect of the alcohol.
targetString: Käk juëc aa lui isopropyl määu wula ethanol kɔ̈u cï kek muɔc iic käk ril cïmen carbomer (polymer käk acrylic acid) gel ic, wula humectant cïmen glycerin pïu ic, wula ayɔ̈k ku bï guɔ a luɔ̈i ku kɔc cɔl aguɔ cïn thiaŋ lui määu ic.

sourceString: Adding diluted hydrogen-peroxide increases further  the antimicrobial activity.Hand sanitizers containing a minimum of 60 to 95% alcohol are efficient germ killers.
targetString: Acan bï ke ye cɔl hydro peroxide tau në kë de wɛ̈ɛ̈c de cin aye yen ca ril. Käk ke weec de cin nɔŋic 60-95% miau apiɛthacan aye kɔ̈m nɔ̈k.

sourceString: Alcohol rub sanitizers kill bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, and some viruses (including HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus, vaccinia, influenza, and hepatitis) and fungi.
targetString: Akɔɔr bï raan yecin ya waak në asabun ago käm cï mɛn de (MRSA ku VRE), tuberculosis, HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus.

sourceString: Alcohol rub sanitizers containing 70% alcohol kill 99.97% (3.5 log reduction, similar to 35 decibel reduction) of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application and 99.99% to 99.999% (4 to 5 log reduction) of the bacteria on hands 1 minute after application.Hand sanitizers are most effective against bacteria and less effective against some viruses.
targetString: Kë nɔŋic miääu ë cï mɛn de 70% e gudhur de 99.97% de kɔ̈m nɔ̈k (3.5-35) në mocmoc ke 30 ku 99.999% (4 agut cë 5) aye nɔ̈k në mocmoc 1. Käk ke lɔ̈ɔ̈k de cin kë aye lui aret në kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria ku ka ce lui apiɛth kenë kɔ̈m ye cɔl virus.

sourceString: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are almost entirely ineffective against norovirus (or Norwalk) type viruses, the most common cause of contagious gastroenteritis.Enough hand antiseptic or alcohol rub must be used to thoroughly wet or cover both hands.
targetString: Kë yenë kɔc ke cin waak nɔŋic miau acï kɔ̈m ebën nyaai. Yen akɔɔr bï raan guthur dït ya tau në yecin ago kɔ̈m nɔ̈k(ama bi cïn cath).

sourceString: The front and back of both hands and between and the ends of all fingers are rubbed for approximately 30 seconds until the liquid, foam or gel is dry.
targetString: Akɔɔr na waak raan yecin ke waak cin kɔ̈u ku cinic në mocmoc ke 30 ago cï ba yɔ̈ɔ̈k ben.

sourceString: Finger tips must be washed well too, rubbing them in both palms.The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing over hand sanitizer rubs, particularly when hands are visibly dirty.
targetString: Riɔp nhïïm akɔɔr bïke waak apiɛth ëya. Cuɔthë ke në cin ciëlic. Ɣän ke gëlë tuany de US acï luel ke cin ya waak cooth arët acan bï acuɔl wën joi nyaai.

sourceString: The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms; however, they should not serve as a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.
targetString: Kë cï kɔc juëc ca gam ë kënë ë kë kɔ̈ɔ̈c ë loi de yic ku ke kam dac nɔ̈k. Akɔɔr bë ya täu në kɔc cin të lïu asubun ku pïu.

sourceString: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.
targetString: Acï kɔɔr ba ya col ke yic miɔ̈c yï cin në asubun wën Ŋɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ ïc miau acan de dɛ̈ɛ̈l ca ril.

sourceString: The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.
targetString: Ëkë yenë asabun nɔŋic miau kɔc kuukë a yenë ke ye cɔl glycerine täu thïn.

sourceString: In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused substantially less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.
targetString: Ɣɔn themë yen,  ke de wɛ̈ɛ̈k de cin nɔŋic miau akɔɔr bï ya yenë ke ye cɔl glycerine ago raan cë kuuk.

sourceString: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs rarely occur.
targetString: Kɔc la gup allergi dermatitis, cït ke gɔ̈t de urticaria wula tuany puör ë riɛm në baŋde määu wula kä kök rɛ̈ɛ̈r määu ic ye kɔc ke cin runy ce rötë dac loi.

sourceString: The lower tendency to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.
targetString: Xɔn yen ë kënë kɔc kuuk yenë ka cïnë ye luel wu bï kɔc ke cin ya waak në asubun ku piu.

sourceString: Despite their effectiveness, non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.
targetString: Kak yenë ke kɔc ke cin piny cïnë pïu acë kam ë dac nɔ̈k.

sourceString: It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.
targetString: Ë kënë yenë ka yenë ye luel wu athabun ku pïu awär ëke yenë cin waakë në gël de lathiëi bec ë käm, rin ŋot käm kɔc luaŋ në ciniic.

sourceString: Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and historically has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.
targetString: Miöm la ic määu e lui tëcït käk cï kek täu ye ic të cï yen luɔi thïn, ku të ŋïc yen ky muɣɛmade ace ŋiɛc lui määu ku kuat määu cï täu thïn.

sourceString: More recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have persistent and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application, unlike alcohol, which has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.
targetString: Kak ke pinyë cïn nɔŋic benzalkoniu acï ke yök ëke lui arët acan a ye kɔm dac nɔ̈k, acï thɔ̈ɔ̈ŋ kenë miau, wën cï yök ke cï lui apiɛth,  acan e raan kuuk guɔp.

sourceString: Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.
targetString: Kɔc juëc wën cin käŋ acï ke ye lëu bïkë asabun xɔc. Aye ke cin waak në ngeeth abac.

sourceString: Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.
targetString: Ngeeth ku tiop alë bïkë lui awarkë pïu cïn ye asabun.

sourceString: One concern is that if the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.
targetString: Kë tɔ̈u, ë na waak yïcin në ngeeth ku tiop nɔŋic käm yenëka cï piɛth.

sourceString: Like soap, ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.
targetString: Cï mɛn da asabun, ngeeth ë käm nɔ̈k eya acan na liäp ye kenë pïu ke ka jal riɛl arët.

sourceString: WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.
targetString: Akutnhom ye cɔl WHO, a aye luel wu ngeeth apiɛth të lïu asabun.

sourceString: Correct handwashing technique recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control  for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:
targetString: Wɛ̈k de cin apiɛth cï të akutnhom tɔ̈ US e Gëlë Tuany ne baŋde wuɔk anɔŋic kuɛrkä:

sourceString: Wet hands with warm or cold running water.
targetString: Miɔ̈c yï cin në piu tuuc wenë pïu lir ëke wat.

sourceString: Running water is recommended because standing basins may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.
targetString: Pïu wat kek kä piɛth awarkë pïu ke xoth acan pïu ke xoth ayic nɔŋ acuɔl.

sourceString: Lather hands by rubbing them with a generous amount of soap, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.
targetString: Coth yï cin apath na thabun piɛth bïk yɔ̈ɔ̈k, agut cïn kɔ̈th, kam kɛmke yiit, ku riɔ̈p thär.

sourceString: Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.
targetString: Thabun ë käm ca bɔ̈ bɛ̈i në raan guöp ku ka cï yök mɛn kɔc juëc aye ke cin lɔɔk  apiɛth të tɔ̈u ë thabun ke ce piu ke pëi.

sourceString: Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
targetString: Akɔɔr ba yï cin coth në mocmoc ke 20.

sourceString: Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin, and scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.
targetString: Guör ye kɔc guur gup e dɔm, ku e köm nyai dɛ̈l ic, ku guör ye kɔc guur gup kam bärkɔ̈u e käm juëc nyai.

sourceString: Rinse well under running water.
targetString: Lɔ̈k yï cin apiɛth në piu watic.

sourceString: Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.
targetString: Lɔ̈k de cin në xothic ë cin bɛr ca yɔ̈k acuɔl.

sourceString: Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.
targetString: Akɔɔr ba yï cin wec në alath cï guɔp acuɔl

sourceString: Wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.
targetString: Cin tiɔp ke ka yenë kɔ̈m ke pïïr thïn arët awar cin cï riɛl. ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye kɔc ke nhïïm lac määr aa riɔ̈p bundit, barcoc nyin, kam cïn, ku riɔ̈ɔ̈p cök.

sourceString: Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may harbor microorganisms.
targetString: Kë yenë tau në kɔc riɔp ku kɔc cin aye kɔ̈m rɔt thiän thïn

sourceString: Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage which can increase the risk for the transmission of infection.
targetString: Diän ye kɔc tɔc e yen cï gam ku bï cin cɔl ala duk, të ye dɛ̈l ril wei kë dɛ̈l ago riäk ku alëu bï tek rot piny ë tuany cɔl ajuak rot.

sourceString: Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries.In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.
targetString: Kë wën e ɣɔc në wëu tɔ̈ piny yenëke lëu bï loi bïnë cin aa lɔɔk të liu pïu-mathura/wula të liu thabun cimën Kä cït yïk wula pïu në kɔc cin në dhiäm nɔ̈ɔ̈k wula kuɔt nɔŋ ɣär piɛth ku/wula loi ŋeth të wïc ëye tënë ŋot ë ke yïk ke. Në ɣän wën cï piu juëc (cï mɛn de thukuul ku bɛɛi mec ke rɔɔk), anɔŋ kä yenë ke mëckëla de pïu cɔ̈k piny, cë mënë "mathura-kääc" ku kɔ̈k tɔ̈ cindɛn ë ɣɔ̈c piiny.

sourceString: A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.
targetString: Akɔɔr bï raan jirkith ya Duɔ̈t në tim thok ke nɔŋ piu ku asubun benë kɔ̈c ke cin ya waak

sourceString: Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.
targetString: Ŋiëc thiäŋ cïn e abaŋ të ye kɔc rɔ̈t tiɛt thïn, ku anaŋ jam alɔŋ thiäŋ guöp ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye kɔc ke laak thïn.

sourceString: A growing volume of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.
targetString: Acï kɔc kɔ̈k luel wu waragɛk xeer wën ye täu në bakana yic apiɛth aka wär alath lɔ̈ŋ guɔp acuɔl.

sourceString: In 2008, a study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.
targetString: Në run de 2008, ke kɔc ke jamiya ye cɔl de pan ye cɔl London acï jam wu waragɛk wën ye täu në bakana yic a yenë kɔc ke cin wec ëtë ŋot tɛ̈n kë në tau në bakana yic.

sourceString: After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.
targetString: Të cïn yï cin piny ku wec në alath cï guɔp acuɔl, ke yïn cï käm juëc arëëtic nɔ̈k 194% ku në cinic ë 254%.

sourceString: Drying with the jet-air dryer resulted in an increase on average of the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.
targetString: Acï kɔɔr bï raan ye cin wec në makana wën ë kɔc wec cïn acan tuäny adet de 42% acï käm ë nyaai ebën agut cï bï lɔ në gudhur de 15%.

sourceString: After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%.The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.
targetString: Të cïn yï cin piny në piu kä asabun ku wec yicin në alath cï guɔp acuɔl ke yïn cï 76% ku në cinic ë 77% de kɔ̈m nɔ̈k. Acï thanytith them eya bïke tiŋ mɛn ye kɔc ë yök ɣöl de wɛk de cin röth ɣok.

sourceString: The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit and potentially contaminating other washroom users and the washroom environment up to 2 metres away.
targetString: Macin  wën ë pïu guɔth wei në raan cïn ë pïu kuɔth wei në thaar kor arët mɛn ye 180m/s(650km/h:400mph). Ku kë kɔm kuɔth wei alɔ bï cuɔt në kaamë mïtïr ke 2 mɛcic arët.

sourceString: Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.
targetString: Macin yenë kɔc kuɔth cïn ë kɔm cuɔt në kaam mɛc arët në kë cï 0.25 metïïr.

sourceString: Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms.In 2005, in a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.
targetString: Waragɛk cï loi ke yenë kɔc ke cin wec acï piɛth. Në run de 2005, ke ye cɔl TÜV ku Umweit acï ke piɛth në kam de alath cï guɔp acuɔl ku waragɛk.

sourceString: The following changes in the bacterial count after drying the hands were observed:
targetString: Kak juëc në biäk de kɔ̈m ye cɔl bacteria acï röth ben wär.

sourceString: Many different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.
targetString: Macinjuëc ke wec de cin acï ke loi ku ka cï yɔ̈ɔ̈k ke wec de cin në alath cï guɔp acuɔl ke yen piɛth.

sourceString: Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative during traveling in the absence of soap and water.
targetString: Wec de cin në asabun thïn cï yenë miau ë piath ke lë yin të mec.

sourceString: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.
targetString: Kë yenë kɔc ke cin wec wën nɔŋic miau apiɛth bï yic näŋ 60%(thiëër dhëtem në buɔɔtic) de miau.

sourceString: Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness (in 1846) in preventing disease in a hospital environment.
targetString: Acï raan ye cɔl Ignaz Semmelweis  luel wu raan lui panakim bï ye cin ya waak në nyindhie acan acï yök ke thiekic arët ne run de 1846 (bianabuur thiëër ku bɛ̈t ku thiëërŋuan ku dhetem).

sourceString: There are electronic devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.
targetString: Anɔŋ wɛ̈ɛ̈th akïm lɛ̈k ku bïk ke cïn lɔk të cï kek nhïïm mär.

sourceString: One study has found decreased infection rates with their use.
targetString: Acï kɔc kɔ̈k luel wu ë makana ye acïn kɔ̈m ca thuuk piny.

sourceString: Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds, using generous amounts of soap and water or gel to lather and rub each part of the hands.
targetString: Dïktor akɔɔr bï yecin ya waak në mocmoc ke 15 kë ye loi në athabun ku pïu wälë miök bë yɔ̈ɔ̈k ku coth röt në cinic.

sourceString: Hands should be rubbed together with digits interlocking.
targetString: Cin akɔɔr bïke coth apiɛth ago kɔ̈m jal.

sourceString: If there is debris under fingernails, a bristle brush may be used to remove it.
targetString: Na nɔŋ kë cï döŋ në cïnic kë ka kɔɔr bï göök bië.

sourceString: Since germs may remain in the water on the hands, it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.
targetString: Akɔɔr bï raan yecin lɔ̈k ku wec yecin në alath cïn guɔp acuɔl.

sourceString: After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water (and open any exit door if necessary).
targetString: Na ca yï cin wec në waragɛk ke yï jɔl mathura thök në ye waragɛk ŋëk ku liëp (dhöl ye në lɔ bïï të lëu ëë rɔt)

sourceString: This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.
targetString: Ë kënë acï yïn bɛr ca tɛ̈u acuɔl në mathura thök.

sourceString: The purpose of hand-washing in the health-care setting is to remove pathogenic microorganisms ("germs") and avoid transmitting them.
targetString: Lui de wɛ̈k de cin panakïm ë bï ("käm") tɔ̈u në raan cin nyaai.

sourceString: The New England Journal of Medicine reports that a lack of hand-washing remains at unacceptable levels in most medical environments, with large numbers of doctors and nurses routinely forgetting to wash their hands before touching patients, thus transmitting microorganisms.
targetString: Te ye kɔc gɔ̈t thin cɔl New England ë jam wu bɛ̈ɛ̈i juëc aŋot ëke kën wɛ̈k de cin gam. Dïktor juëc aye nhiim dac maar ku cïkë ke cin piny ku jekë kɔc tuany go jak.

sourceString: One study showed that proper hand-washing and other simple procedures can decrease the rate of catheter-related bloodstream infections by 66 percent.The World Health Organization has published a sheet demonstrating standard hand-washing and hand-rubbing in health-care sectors.
targetString: Kɔc kɔ̈k acï jam wu wɛ̈k de cin yenëke Thɔ̈l tuany yenë tuany gël wei ku kɔ̈k wën ye dïktor ke loi alë bïke tuany gël në biak de 66%. Akuthnom ë Pinynhom Mɛ̈t në Pial ecï waragɛk wɛ̈kë kɔc ke cin loi. Anɔŋic të ye wëëk kɔc cin panakïm.

sourceString: The draft guidance of hand hygiene by the organization can also be found at its website for public comment.
targetString: Ajuiɛɛr de biäk de wɛɛk de cin acï manadhama tau në website nyin.

sourceString: A relevant review was conducted by Whitby et al.
targetString: Acï tïŋ në kë ye cɔl Whitby et al.

sourceString: Commercial devices can measure and validate hand hygiene, if demonstration of regulatory compliance is required.
targetString: Macin de wëu ë gudhur cenë kɔc ke cïn them acan bï tïŋ mɛn cï kɔc gäm.

sourceString: The World Health Organization has "Five Moments" for washing hands:
targetString: Akutnhom ë Pinynhom Mɛ̈t në Pial anɔŋ "dhöl ke dhïc" de wɛ̈ɛ̈kë cin:

sourceString: after exposure to blood/body fluids
targetString: Të cïnë riɛm yï jak cïn.

sourceString: before an aseptic task, and
targetString: Ke yï kën lui cï kör në wathak loi.

sourceString: after patient care.The addition of antiseptic chemicals to soap ("medicated" or "antimicrobial" soaps) confers killing action to a hand-washing agent.
targetString: Ku të cïn raan Tuany tök Akɔɔr bï raan ye cin waak në asabun acan yenë ke kɔ̈m dac nɔ̈k.

sourceString: Such killing action may be desired prior to performing surgery or in settings in which antibiotic-resistant organisms are highly prevalent.To 'scrub' one's hands for a surgical operation, it is necessary to have a tap that can be turned on and off without touching it with the hands, some chlorhexidine or iodine wash, sterile towels for drying the hands after washing, and a sterile brush for scrubbing and another sterile instrument for cleaning under the fingernails.
targetString: Ëkenë alë bï ya loi agot dïkor ke kën raan guɔ reetic wenë ɣan wën juëc ë kɔ̈m c̈i wɛ̈l ye cɔl antibiotic dhaal. Na waak yïcin të ler yïn ɣöl de riɛɛr de yic ke ka kɔɔr bï naŋ mathura ye thök ku liep ke kenë jak në kɔc cin wene wɛ̈l ye cɔl Chlorheidine ku iodine. Akɔɔr bï naŋ alath piɛth wën yenë kɔc ke cin waak të cin piny.

sourceString: All jewelry should be removed.
targetString: Ka yekë cëŋ në kɔc cin a yeke nyaai ebën.

sourceString: This procedure requires washing the hands and forearms up to the elbow, usually 2–6 minutes.
targetString: Luɔië akɔɔr bï raan yecin agut cï ye kɔɔr nyic waak në athabun në digikat ke 2-6.

sourceString: Long scrub-times (10 minutes) are not necessary.
targetString: Acï kɔɔr bï raan yecin bɛr waak në (digikat ke 10) acan acïn kë kony.

sourceString: When rinsing, water on the forearms must be prevented from running back to the hands.
targetString: Na lɔk raan yecin ke ka cïn kɔɔr bï pïu ke raan kɔɔr bɛr lɔ në cïnic.

sourceString: After hand-washing is completed, the hands are dried with a sterile cloth and a surgical gown is donned.
targetString: Na ca cïn thök në wɛ̈ɛ̈kke yï jɔl yecin weec në alath cïn guɔp acuɔl.

sourceString: To reduce the spread of germs, it is better to wash the hands or use a hand antiseptic before and after tending to a sick person.
targetString: Acan bï tuany rɔt cë xok arëëtic, akɔɔr bï kɔc ke cin ya waak në nyindhie.

sourceString: For control of staphylococcal infections in hospitals, it has been found that the greatest benefit from hand-cleansing came from the first 20% of washing, and that very little additional benefit was gained when hand cleansing frequency was increased beyond 35%.
targetString: Të kɔɔr bïnë tuany ye bɛ̈i në kɔ̈m ye cɔl staphylococcus gël ë bï kɔc ke cin ya waak në nyindhie baai ku panakïm e ye dhuɔ̈k në 20%. Acï yɔ̈k ke yen bï kɔc ke cin waak yenë kë tueŋ de gël de tuɛnytuɛny kɔ̈k ecï juak bë ɣet në 35% nhom tueŋ.

sourceString: Washing with plain soap results in more than triple the rate of bacterial infectious disease transmitted to food as compared to washing with antibacterial soap.Comparing hand-rubbing with alcohol-based solution with hand washing with antibacterial soap for a median time of 30 seconds each showed that the alcohol hand-rubbing reduced bacterial contamination 26% more than the antibacterial soap.
targetString: Week de cin në asabun yeẗok ë tuany ye wuɔɔk në kuinic gël në doric na diak. Na thiɔŋë cuuth de cin në asabun ku cuuth de cin wel de bacteria në mocmoc ke 30, ke ka yök wɛɛk de cin në asabun ye kɔm nɔ̈k aret awar wɛɛk de cin në ye wɛ̈l de kɔm në të cït tënë 26%.

sourceString: But soap and water is more effective than alcohol-based hand rubs for reducing H1N1 influenza A virus and Clostridium difficile spores from hands.Interventions to improve hand hygiene in healthcare settings can involve education for staff on hand washing, increasing the availability of alcohol-based hand rub, and written and verbal reminders to staff.
targetString: Pïu ku asabun apiɛth bïnë raan yecin ya waak në nyindhie acan awar kë wën nɔŋic miau ago H1N1influenza A ku Clostridium difficild spores dhuk nyin piny agokë jäl në cinic. Anɔŋ käk cïke tau cï mɛn de piöc në biak de wɛ̈ɛ̈k de cin.

sourceString: There is a need for more research into which of these interventions are most effective in different healthcare settings.
targetString: Apiɛth bï dïktor kɔɔr rïc ku tïŋ mɛn asubun ku pïu yekë tuɛnytuny gël arëëtic.

sourceString: In developing countries, hand washing with soap is recognized as a cost-effective, essential tool for achieving good health, and even good nutrition.
targetString: Në bɛ̈ɛ̈i ŋot ëke yïïk ke, a yeke yɔ̈k ke wɛɛk de cin në asubun ku pïu ye tuany tuany gël.

sourceString: However, a lack of reliable water supply, soap or hand washing facilities in people's homes, at schools and at the workplace make it a challenge to achieve universal hand washing behaviors.
targetString: Dɛ̈r ë ya, liu de piu ku asabune xan kɔ̈k cï mɛn de baai, thukul ku ɣän ke loi alëu bï ajuiɛɛr gël bï rɔt cë lëu.

sourceString: For example, in most of rural Africa hand washing taps close to every private or public toilet are scarce, even though cheap options exist to build hand washing stations.
targetString: Cï mɛn de bɛ̈ɛ̈i kënë yïïk tɔ̈u në Africa, xan ke wɛɛk de cin a lik arët ke cakic cë ril bï xan ke lɔ̈k de cin loi.

sourceString: However, low hand washing rates rather can also be the result of engrained habits rather than due to a lack of soap or water.
targetString: Kë tɔ̈u, kɔc juëc acï kë nhiaar bïkë ke cin waak ke käk ke lɔ̈k de cin cäk tɔ̈u.

sourceString: The promotion and advocacy of hand washing with soap can influence policy decisions, raise awareness about the benefits of hand washing and lead to long-term behavior change of the population.
targetString: Akɔɔr bï kɔc rɔth juiir ku lɔ kɔc në bɛ̈ɛ̈i yic bï kɔc lɔ piööc piath de bïkë kɔc kecin waak.

sourceString: For this to work effectively, monitoring and evaluation are necessary.
targetString: Acan bï kënë lui apiɛth, akɔɔr bï tït de nyïn ca dït

sourceString: A systematic review of 70 studies found that community-based approaches are effective at increasing hand washing in LMICs, while social marketing campaigns are less effective.One example for hand washing promotion in schools is the "Three Star Approach" by UNICEF that encourages schools to take simple, inexpensive steps to ensure that students wash their hands with soap, among other hygienic requirements.
targetString: Kɔc cï kënë laaric na 70 aye jam wu ajuiɛɛr de bɛ̈ɛ̈i në biäk de lɔ̈k de cin  alui arëëtic në LMICs,ajuiɛɛr de wɛɛk de cin ye luel thuuk acïn kë kony arët, kë wɛ̈t ë lɔŋde thuk aacï piɛth apiɛth. Töŋ e nyoth dë lɔ̈kë cin cuɔt në thukuulic e "Kuɛl ke diäk en ë ye Buɔth" në UNICEF e thukuul jääm  bïk në kä piɔlic, akäth thii cë rilic ago mïth thukuul ke cin awaak athabun, në kɔ̈k ke piath wïcke.

sourceString: When minimum standards are achieved, schools can move from one to ultimately three stars.
targetString: Na cï të ë kör yen yök, ke thukuul alë bïkë röt cuɔt në diäk.

sourceString: Building hand washing stations can be a part of hand washing promotion campaigns that are carried out in order to reduce diseases and child mortality.
targetString: Yïŋ de xan ke piny de cin apiɛth arët acan bï tuany rɔt gël  ku thon de mïth kor.

sourceString: Global Hand washing Day is another example of an awareness-raising campaign that is trying to achieve behavior change.As a result of the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic, UNICEF promoted the adoption of a handwashing emoji.
targetString: Köl de wɛɛk de cin wën ye pinynhom ebën theek ë ye nyuɔɔth ke riliic acan ayenë kë loi rɔt ŋic . Në kë de 2019-20 tuany de pinynhom cɔl korona,  UNICEF acï ajuiɛɛr de wɛ̈k de cin lɔ̈m ke yic.

sourceString: Few studies have considered the overall cost effectiveness of hand washing in developing countries in relationship to DALYs averted.
targetString: Kɔc lik acï jam wu ajuiɛɛr de wɛ̈k de cin apiɛth në bɛ̈ɛ̈i wën ŋoot ëke yïïk kek në mäth welë DALYs.

sourceString: However, one review suggests that promoting hand washing with soap is significantly more cost-effective than other water and sanitation interventions.
targetString: Ku këya, kɔc kɔ̈k acï kë gam ke lɔ̈k de cin në thabun në nyindhiɛ apiɛth kuka aräkïïth rɛ̈k awär bï raan ye cin lɔɔk në pïu ka pëi në biäk  de bï tuany gël.

sourceString: The importance of hand washing for human health – particularly for people in vulnerable circumstances like mothers who had just given birth or wounded soldiers in hospitals – was first recognized in the mid 19th century by two pioneers of hand hygiene: the Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis who worked in Vienna, Austria and Florence Nightingale, the English "founder of modern nursing".
targetString: Rilic yic de wɛ̈k de cin tënɔŋ pial de guɔp de raan cï mɛn de raan cï dhiɔp ku tïŋ liaac akɔn yök në ruɔn në 19th century (run de thiëër ku dhoŋuan) në  kɔc ka rou ëke cïke tau xöl de döm.

sourceString: At that time most people still believed that infections were caused by foul odors called miasmas.
targetString: Në ye thɛɛr xɔn, a ye kɔc juëc luel wu tuany aye acuɔl bɛ̈i.

sourceString: In the 1980s, foodborne outbreaks and healthcare-associated infections led the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to more actively promote hand hygiene as an important way to prevent the spread of infection.
targetString: Në 1980s ic, tuɛnytuɛny yeke yök në cämic akë cï juëc go ɣän ke Gël de Tuany tɔ̈ Amërika wɛ̈k de cin lɛ̈k kɔc ke bï ya loi në dhöl bïnë lɔ becë tuany ya gël.

sourceString: The outbreak of swine flu in 2009 and the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to increased awareness in many countries of the importance of washing hands with soap to protect oneself from such infectious diseases.
targetString: Lɔ bïe de tuany ye cɔl swine flu në 2009  ku tuany ye cɔl COVID_19 në 2020  acï wɛ̈k de cin ca ye kë piɛɛth arëëtic.

sourceString: For example, posters with "correct hand washing techniques" were hung up next to hand washing sinks in public toilets and in the toilets of office buildings and airports in Germany.
targetString: Cï mɛn de thuraat cï ke thuɔric "dhɔ̈ɔ̈l puɔth ye kɔc ke cin lɔɔk" aacï kek nöök të thiäk kek të ye kɔc ke cin lɔɔk bakanat ye raan ebën la roor thïn ku bakanat maktap ku käk rɛ̈ɛ̈r matar pan Germany.

sourceString: The phrase "washing one's hands of" something, means declaring one's unwillingness to take responsibility for the thing or share complicity in it.
targetString: Këye luel "lɔ̈k cin ye raan ye cin lɔɔk" wɛ̈tde ic e mukthulia raan ebën ku nyin tït kɔc kök wula bï naŋ kuɔny thïn.

sourceString: It originates from the bible passage in Matthew where Pontius Pilate washed his hands of the decision to crucify Jesus Christ, but has become a phrase with a much wider usage in some English communities.
targetString: A jɔk rɔt në baibolic në kitap de Mathayo xɔn cenë raan ye cɔl Pontiu Pilate yecin waak ke jai bï yecu piät.

sourceString: In Shakespeare's Macbeth, Lady Macbeth begins to compulsively wash her hands in an attempt to cleanse an imagined stain, representing her guilty conscience regarding crimes she had committed and induced her husband to commit.
targetString: Në Shakespeare's Macbeth, tiŋ ye cɔl Macbeth acï ye cin lɔɔk ku bä acuɔl ya laak wei ye cin, rin ye yen rot gök ke rɛ̈ɛ̈c cï looi ku rin cï yen muɔnyde cɔl aloi kerac.

sourceString: It has also been found that people, after having recalled or contemplated unethical acts, tend to wash hands more often than others, and tend to value hand washing equipment more.
targetString: Kɔc kɔ̈k acï bɛ̈n yɔ̈k ke piɛth bï raan ye cin ya waak acan acï ke yɔ̈k ke rilic në biäk de gël de tuany.

sourceString: Furthermore, those who are allowed to wash their hands after such a contemplation are less likely to engage in other "cleansing" compensatory actions, such as volunteering.
targetString: Ëya, Kɔc wën ye ke piɔ̈l bïkë ke cin waak në luɔ̈t acï lë bïkë rɔ̈t ya tɔ̈u në loiloi ke cuöl ë "wääk" cin yic cï mɛn de loi da abac.

sourceString: Religions prescribe hand washing for both hygienic and symbolic purposes.Symbolic hand washing, using water but no soap to wash hands, is a part of ritual hand washing featured in many religions, including Bahá'í Faith, Hinduism, tevilah and netilat yadayim in Judaism, Lavabo in Christianity, and Wudhu in Islam.Religions also prescribe hygienic hand washing, especially after certain actions.
targetString: Kɔc ke kanitha a ye kë cin waak acan bike tuany gël ku ka yeke cin waak ë ya ke ye kɛɛr de kë lajik. Kɛ̈ɛ̈r de kë lajik acï në kɔc ke cin ye waak në asubun cï mɛn de Bahäi Faith, Hinduism, tevilah ku netitatyadayim në Judaism yic.

sourceString: Hinduism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands after using the toilet.
targetString: Hinduism, Judaism ku Islam a ye kecin waak të cïnë raan lɔ bakana.

sourceString: And, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands before and after every meal.
targetString: Ku dïn ye cɔl Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism ku Islam a ye kecin waak të kɔɔr bïnë raan cam ku të cïnë raan cam.

sourceString: Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19
targetString: Gël de rɔt ne tuany ye cɔl COVID-19 në xan ke luɔi.

sourceString: Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19 are the application of occupational safety and health methodologies for hazard controls to the prevention of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
targetString: Gël de rɔt ne ɣän ke lui ë bï tuany ye cɔl COVID-19 gël bï kɔc në tuany de coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19).

sourceString: The proper hazard controls in the workplace depend on the worksite and job task, based on a risk assessment of sources of exposure, disease severity in the community, and risk factors of individual workers who may be vulnerable to contracting COVID-19.
targetString: Thɔ̈l piɛth ë gël röth tëde lui ë bï dhɔ̈l në bïnë ke tuaany yök kan nyic ku bï raan nyic raan lë bï dac tuany në COVID-19

sourceString: According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers, for which basic infection prevention measures are recommended, including hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.
targetString: Në biäk de pan ye cɔl U.S Akutnhomë Muk de Luɔi Piɛth ku Pial (AMLPP), loiloi cïnë benë ke tuany dac aye loiloi wenë cenë raan ke dac thiäk kenë kɔc juëc aretic, ku nɔŋ thɔ̈ɔ̈l yenëke ye tuanyë gël, cï mɛn de wɛ̈ɛ̈k de cin,  bï kɔc cï tuaany ya rëër në bääi yic, ku mɛc de yic ku jal ya bï ɣän yeke jak ya weec në nyindhie.

sourceString: Medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact with people who are not known or suspected with COVID-19, but may be infected due to ongoing community transmission or international travel.
targetString: Lui lë bïnë raan tuany dac yök ë loi yenë raan col ë yök kenë kɔc kɔ̈k yeke diu cït ëke tuany në COVID-19, lakin alëu bïk wuɔk në wɛ̈të lɔtueŋ ë wuɔk de wuötic wälë cääth loi röt në piny nhom.

sourceString: This includes workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.
targetString: Kënë anɔŋic kɔc lui thïäk thook kekë juör ëbɛ̈n cït yïk thukuul ɣän, cï ke dïl në ceŋ kɔc juëc, ku jɔla ɣän kɔ̈k ke ɣɛɛc kuöt nhïm.

sourceString: Hazard controls for this group, in addition to basic infection prevention measures, include ventilation using high-efficiency air filters, sneeze guards, and having personal protective equipment available in case a person with COVID-19 is encountered.
targetString: Gël de  kë: näk raan ëke de ya akutnhom ë. Kënë ëke dhitë në ka juëc ke gël cï mɛn de bï raan ya rëër xɔl nɔŋ alir dït, ku bï raan ya tiim ke ce wum kum ku bï raan ya ceŋ në alɛth ke tït de tuany.

sourceString: OSHA considers healthcare and mortuary workers exposed to known or suspected person with COVID-19 to be at high exposure risk, which increases to very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected person with COVID-19.
targetString: OSHA ë jam wu kɔc lui xɔ̈n de guɔp cï thou në COVID-19 alë bïke dac tuany, ku jal raac aret të nɔŋ ɣen ka yeke muɔi në guɔp cï thou guɔp, wenë bï raan thueithuei löm tënɔŋ raan tuany në COVID-19.

sourceString: Hazard controls appropriate for these workers include engineering controls such as negative pressure ventilation rooms, and personal protective equipment appropriate to the job task.
targetString: Gël de kä näk kɔc apiɛth kënë kɔc lui në ye xan këë, ku bï raan ye ceŋ në aduot ke gël rɔŋ kenë ëke loi ë.

sourceString: COVID-19 outbreaks can have several effects within the workplace.
targetString: Täu de ye tuanyë COVID-19 abï biäk de ka loi kek riɔk.

sourceString: Workers may be absent from work due to becoming sick, needing to care for others, or from fear of possible exposure.
targetString: Kɔc ke luɔi alë bïkë cë bɔ̈ ago kë ce tuany, ku bï raan cï tuany kɔc lui kenë yen ce xok.

sourceString: Patterns of commerce may change, both in terms of what goods are demanded, and the means of acquiring these goods (such as shopping at off-peak hours or through delivery or drive-through services).
targetString: Biäk de tajir abï rɔt, acan kɔc juëc acï bï bɛr ya dac xöc në cën wëu ku në thɛɛr yenë thuuk thök.

sourceString: Lastly, shipments of items from geographic areas severely affected by COVID-19 may be interrupted.An infectious disease preparedness and response plan can be used to guide protective actions.
targetString: Në kë da kɛr den, kɔc ye kä ke thuuk caath wiiric acï ke bï piɔl bïke caath ke jël ke pan nɔŋic tuany ye cɔl COVID-19

sourceString: Plans address the levels of risk associated with various worksites and job tasks, including sources of exposure, risk factors arising from home and community settings, and risk factors of individual workers such as old age or chronic medical conditions.
targetString: Aguiɛr e loiloi thääny thook kek tuany ku käk loiloi ku të ye kɔc lui thïn, käk jɔk baai ku akut baai, ku käk kɔc lui jɔ̈ɔ̈r cïmen kɔc cï dhiɔp wula kɔc la gup ke jɔ̈ɔ̈r alɔŋ pial guöpden ic.

sourceString: They also outline controls necessary to address those risks, and contingency plans for situations that may arise as a result of outbreaks.
targetString: Aye lui ë ya ne gël de rɔt ne ka lë bïkë rɔth jɔk në gɛɛr ë thaar.

sourceString: Infectious disease preparedness and response plans may be subject to national or subnational recommendations.
targetString: Aguiɛr de gɛ̈l e tuanyë ku aguiɛr të bï tuany cuɔp thïn e kë ye akumadït wula akuma kor luel yen abï ya buɔth ic.

sourceString: Objectives for response to an outbreak include reducing transmission among staff, protecting people who are at higher risk for adverse health complications, maintaining business operations, and minimizing adverse effects on other entities in their supply chains.
targetString: Ke kɔɔr në yëne yic, ë bï tuaany dhuuk nyin cën ku bï kɔc lë bïkë tuany dac yök gël apiɛth ku tajiir ce riäk ku bï ka rɛɛc ke ye tuanyë thuuk nyïn thïn

sourceString: The disease severity in the community where the business is located affects the responses taken.
targetString: Dït de ye tuanyë në bɛ̈ɛ̈i loi ëke tajiir thin acï käŋ ca lëu röt

sourceString: The hierarchy of hazard controls is a framework widely used in occupational safety and health to group hazard controls by effectiveness.
targetString: Tëcït të ye tuany gɛ̈l thïn e luɔi ye luɔ̈i abaŋ pial guöp lui alɔŋ tuɛnytuɛny ŋiɛc luɔiden.

sourceString: Where COVID-19 hazards cannot be eliminated, the most effective controls are engineering controls, followed by administrative controls, and lastly personal protective equipment.
targetString: Ke kɔɔr bï loi Pan nɔŋic tuany de COVID-19 ë bï kɔc ya ceŋ në  alɛth ke gël de tuany

sourceString: Engineering controls involve isolating employees from work-related hazards without relying on worker behavior, and can be the most cost-effective solution to implement.
targetString: Gël de ye tuanyë akɔɔr bï raan lui ya tau tëde  yetök ku ka lë bi yakë piɛth wën në bï rɔt dac loi.

sourceString: Administrative controls are changes in work policy or procedures that require action by the worker or employer.
targetString: Gël de ye tuanyë në biäk de bäny de loi ë bï lɔŋ ke loi tau.

sourceString: Personal protective equipment (PPE) is considered less effective than engineering and administrative controls, but can help prevent some exposures.
targetString: Käke Ŋɛk de Gëlë Guöp (KŊG) aye yök kë cï lui apiɛth wär lööŋ akuma tiët nyin lakin alëu bï kony në wuɔk kɔ̈k.

sourceString: All types of PPE must be selected based upon the hazard to the worker, properly fitted as applicable (e.g., respirators), consistently and properly worn, regularly inspected, maintained, and replaced, as necessary, and properly removed, cleaned, and stored or disposed of to avoid contamination.
targetString: Alɛ̈th ke gël de tuany PPE ebën akɔɔr bï ya lɔc në biak de kɔc lui, piɛth de (cï mɛn de käŋ ke wëi), ŋic cëŋ de, gël de ku ŋic bï de bɛi ago tuany rɔt cë ɣook.

sourceString: According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers.
targetString: Tënɔŋ U.S. në biäkë Akutnhomë Muk de Luɔi Piɛth ku Pial (AMLPP) aa yeke luel  wu kɔc lui në xan cïn kɔc juëc acï lë bïkë dac tuany.

sourceString: Basic infection prevention measures recommended for all workplaces include frequent and thorough hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette including covering coughs and sneezes, providing tissues and trash receptacles, preparing for telecommuting or staggered shifts if needed, discouraging workers from using others' tools and equipment, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.
targetString: Dhɔ̈ɔ̈l ke gël de tuany aye bï cin ya waak në nyindiɛ, bï kɔc lui ya rëër baai tenɔŋ ke guup tuany, bï thok ku wum ya kum të ɣɔl yin ka të tïm yïn, bï kɔc lui kak ken ke lui cë ye rɔm ku jal ya bï ɣan ke lui ya cën acuɔl.

sourceString: Prompt identification and isolation of potentially infectious individuals is a critical step in protecting workers, customers, visitors, and others at a worksite.
targetString: Dhɔ̈l piɛth dɛ̈t de gël de ye tuanyë ë bï raan tuany ya tau tëde yetök acan bï kɔc lui, kɔc ɣɔ̈c, kamaan, ku kɔc kɔ̈k gël.

sourceString: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness are to stay home until they are free of fever, signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines, and that sick leave policies are flexible, permit employees to stay home to care for a sick family member, and that employees are aware of these policies.
targetString: Akutnhom ye cɔl CDC de USA ë jam wu ka kɔɔr bï raan cï tuany ya ca rɛ̈ɛ̈r baai ku bɔ̈ në juiɛ̈rë ago cï bï kït cït mɛn da atui jal, atui ku kït juëc kɔ̈k në thɛɛr ke 24 yic ke raan kën dek në wal wën atui dhuk piny, ku löŋ ke tuany aa laau, cakë raan lui tïŋ raan tuany baa, ku kɔc lui kë aa ŋic ë loŋë.

sourceString: According to OSHA, medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact within six feet (1.8 m) of people who are not known or suspected COVID-19 patients, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 due to ongoing community transmission around the business location, or because the individual has recent international travel to a location with widespread COVID-19 transmission.
targetString: Në biäk de OSHA, aye luel wu kɔc lui në ɣän juëc ë kɔc thïn ku thiɔ̈ɔ̈k kɔc yic (1.8m) alë bï dac tuany në COVID-19 wenë SARS-CoV-2 në wɛ̈të lɔtueŋ de wuɔk loi röt në wuötic ɣän ke tujäria, wälë raan piɔc jäl në cäthic në ɣän cï COVID-19 larär bec.

sourceString: These include workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.Engineering controls for this and higher risk groups include installing high-efficiency air filters, increasing ventilation rates, installing physical barriers such as clear plastic sneeze guards, and installing a drive-through window for customer service.Administrative controls for this and higher risk groups include encouraging sick workers to stay at home, replacing face-to-face meetings with virtual communications, establishing staggered shifts, discontinuing nonessential travel to locations with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks, developing emergency communications plans including a forum for answering workers' concerns, providing workers with up-to-date education and training on COVID-19 risk factors and protective behaviors, training workers who need to use protecting clothing and equipment how to use it, providing resources and a work environment that promotes personal hygiene, requiring regular hand washing, limiting customers' and the public's access to the worksite, and posting signage about hand washing and other COVID-19 protective measures.Depending on the work task, workers with at least medium exposure risk may need to wear personal protective equipment including some combination of gloves, a gown, a face shield or face mask, or goggles.
targetString: Ekenë anɔŋic kɔc lui në ɣän ke tëëŋ cï mɛn de thukuul, ɣän nɔŋ raan gääk arët, ku thuɔ̈k dït. Madithïn acï kë alir thimic loi, dhit kë wëi yic, loi kë ke yenë tïm thïn, ku jal ya këde kɔc ɣɔ̈c. Ajuiɛɛr dɛ̈t ë bï raan cï tuany ya rëër baai, bï amɛ̈ɛ̈t ya loi në cabaka nyin, ku bï caath cï yic ril piɔl bï raan cë lɔ pan nɔŋic COVID-19, akɔɔr bï cabaka loi benë thuɛɛl ke kɔc ke lui ya thuk nhim, bï kɔc ke luɔi ya lɛ̈k ke loi rɔt në biak de COVID-19 ku jal ya gël de, bï kɔc piööc të ye cëŋ alɛ̈th ke gël de rɔt ku ɣän ke loi ku bï raan ya rëër ke cïn acuɔl, akɔɔr wɛ̈ɛ̈k de cin në nyindhiɛ, ku bï kɔc ɣɔ̈c ya lïik ku bï thurat ke të ye pïny kɔc cin piat ku kɔ̈k ke gël de ̈COVID-19. Kɔc lui në ɣän dïtë tuany alë bïkë ya ceŋ ne alɛ̈th ke gël cï mɛn de balomat, jalabiya de panakïm, alath de wum  wenë matharat.

sourceString: Workers in this risk group rarely require use of respirators.
targetString: Kɔc lui në ye xan këë akɔɔr bïke ya ceŋ në ka ke wëi.

sourceString: If a person becomes sick on an airplane, proper controls to protect workers and other passengers include separating the sick person from others by a distance of 6 feet, designating one crew member to serve the sick person, and offering a face mask to the sick person or asking the sick person to cover their mouth and nose with tissues when coughing or sneezing.
targetString: Na cï raan tuany në thayara yic ke ka kɔɔr bï kɔc gël në yen cï mɛn de bï tau tëde yetök bï mɛi në cök ke 6, bï raan tök ca tiët nyin në yen, ku bï raan tuany ca kum ye wum ku yethok në alath cïn guɔp acuɔl.

sourceString: Cabin crew should wear disposable medical gloves when tending to a sick traveler or touching body fluids or potentially contaminated surfaces, and possibly additional personal protective equipment if the sick traveler has fever, persistent cough, or difficulty breathing.
targetString: Kɔc ke thayara alë bïkë ya ceŋ në balombat në kecin a gokë ce wuɔɔk, ku jal ya käk ke gël tënɔŋë raan atui, ɣɔl baric ku wëëi riilic.

sourceString: Gloves and other disposable items should be disposed of in a biohazard bag, and contaminated surfaces should be cleaned and disinfected afterwards.For commercial shipping, including cruise ships and other passenger vessels, hazard controls include postponing travel when sick, and self-isolating and informing the onboard medical center immediately if one develops a fever or other symptoms while on board.
targetString: Balomat ku alɛ̈th ke panakïm akɔɔr bïke ya ceŋ ku cuɛtë të cïke cuɔl në kɔc lui në thayara. Ku ɣän cï acuɔl yök akɔɔr bïke ya weec. Kɔ̈k cï mɛn de riŋ wiric alë ke ya piɔl të cï raan tuany.

sourceString: Ideally, medical follow-up should occur in the isolated person's cabin.For schools and childcare facilities, CDC recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Akɔɔr bï kɔc cï tuany ya kuanycök në bɛ̈ɛ̈i ken yic bïkë lɔ tïŋ në tau den. Në biak de thukuul ku rodha, CDC acï thukuul ca thök thook në thaar kor.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as canceling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: Na tɔu tuany ke ye rɔt wɔɔk amääth në bɛ̈ɛ̈i yic ke ka kɔɔr bï kɔc ke yic ya mec wei ku mäl kɔc cäth, akuötnhom, ku ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n kök kɔc mat nhïïm cïmen käk ye looi bi kɔc gup pial wula ɣɔ̈ɔ̈n ye kɔc piööc waak thïn wula miɛ̈th matamic, juɛ̈ŋ ic piny käk ye kɔc ke nyuc, kam ye kɔc bɛ̈n ku kam ye kɔc luɔny aɣer bï kɔc jäl, dhukpiny nɛ̈m ye kɔc rɔ̈t nem, ku lui maktap tën mïth naŋ gup kïït juäi.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.For law enforcement personnel performing daily routine activities, the immediate health risk is considered low by CDC.
targetString: Na tɔ̈ wuɔk dït në wuöt thii, ë lɔŋë mecë kɔc yic ciën e tɔ̈, kë thïök de thukuul thook alëu bï cuɔt. Tënë kɔc muk lööŋ e lui në käkë köl thok abɛ̈n ke mëckëla de pial aye yök kë tɔ̈ piny në CDC.

sourceString: Law enforcement officials who must make contact with individuals confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 are recommended to follow the same guidelines as emergency medical technicians, including proper personal protective equipment.
targetString: Kɔc ke tɛ̈u de lɔ̈ŋ yekë diu cït ëtë ke cï tuany në COVID-19 apiɛth bïkë Thɔ̈l ke tït de rɔt ya kuanycök.

sourceString: If close contact occurs during apprehension, workers should clean and disinfect their duty belt and gear prior to reuse using a household cleaning spray or wipe, and follow standard operating procedures for the containment and disposal of used PPE and for containing and laundering clothes.
targetString: Na cï kɔc yic thiɔ̈k ë të dɔmë raan, ke kɔc ke loi alë bïkë kak kën ke loi wec në asubun. Apiɛth ëya bï raan kɛ̈ɛ̈r ke gël kuany cök në të yenë PPE luɔi thïn ku të yen alɛ̈th ku kɔ̈rdɛn luɔi thïn

sourceString: OSHA considers certain healthcare and mortuary workers to be at high or very high categories of exposure risk.
targetString: OSHA ë jam wu kɔc lui pan akim ku kɔc ë lui xöt de guup cï thou alë bïkë tuany dac yök.

sourceString: High exposure risk jobs include healthcare delivery, support, laboratory, and medical transport workers who are exposed to known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Kɔc lë bïkë tuany dac yök aye kɔc lui pan akim ku kɔc ë kɔc tuany lɛr pan akïm kɔc tuany në COVID-19 tok

sourceString: These become very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Kɔc lui pan akim cï mɛn de dïktor ë lui ɣöt de them ë kɔc ku dïktor ë kɔc tuany në COVID-19 tök

sourceString: Aerosol-generating procedures include intubation, cough induction procedures, bronchoscopies, some dental procedures and exams, or invasive specimen collection.
targetString: Ka ye dïktor ke looi cï mɛn de tɛ̈u de lithik në raan piɔ̈u ago raan wëi apiɛth ku jal ya kɔc ë thueithuei them.

sourceString: High exposure risk mortuary jobs include workers involved in preparing the bodies of people who had known or suspected cases of COVID-19 at the time of their death; these become very high exposure risk if they perform an autopsy.Additional engineering controls for these risk groups include isolation rooms for patients with known or suspected COVID-19, including when aerosol-generating procedures are performed.
targetString: Kɔc ë lui xöt de guup cï thou alë bïkë tuany dac yök. Kɔc ë kɔc cï tuany në COVID-19 tök aye dac tuany. Acan bï tuany rɔt cë ɣok ke ka kɔɔr bï kɔc tuany në COVID-19 ya täu tëden ke pɛɛi.

sourceString: Specialized negative pressure ventilation may be appropriate in some healthcare and mortuary settings.
targetString: Xöt ke guup cë thou apiɛth bïkë ya naŋ awëër dït bï alir ya ben xöt

sourceString: Specimens should be handled with Biosafety Level 3 precautions.
targetString: Thueithuei leer ëke të de them akɔɔr bïke ya muuk në gudhur de 3 në biak de gël.

sourceString: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that incoming patients be separated into distinct waiting areas depending on whether they are a suspected COVID-19 case.In addition to other PPE, OSHA recommends respirators for those who work within 6 feet of patients known to be, or suspected of being, infected with SARS-CoV-2, and those performing aerosol-generating procedures.
targetString: Akutnhom ë Pinynhom Mɛ̈t në Pial (APMP) ë jam wu kɔc bïkë pan akim akɔɔr bïke ya täu në ɣän kën ka pɛɛi të yenë ke yök cït ëke tuany në COVID-19. Në dɛ̈t mɛtë thïn tënë kɔ̈k ke PPE, OSHA e käke wëëï thany cök bï ke yiëk kɔc ë lui tënë ayanïïn nyic në akäthic ke 6, wälë kɔc diw keek lɔn cï kek wuɔk në SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: In the United States, NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirators or better must be used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams.
targetString: Pan ye cɔl Amërika, NIOSH acï ke ye täu në kɔc wuum ye cɔl N95 loi. Abï naŋ piööc bï loi ago ka cï ke loi kë ya luɔ̈i apiɛth

sourceString: Other types of respirators can provide greater protection and improve worker comfort.The WHO does not recommend coveralls, as COVID-19 is a respiratory disease rather than being transmitted through bodily fluids.
targetString: Kɔ̈k yenë ke wëi kuɔny apiɛth arëëtic acan acï nyic loi. Akutnhom ye cɔl WHO aken gam bï wum ya col ke kum acan covid_19 ë tuany de guyɔɔk.

sourceString: WHO recommends only a surgical mask for point-of-entry screening personnel.
targetString: Akutnhom ye cɔl WHO ë jam wu bike kɔc ke wum ye kum në alath thïn kor.

sourceString: For those who are collecting respiratory specimens from, caring for, or transporting COVID-19 patients without any aerosol-generating procedures, WHO recommends a surgical mask, goggles, or face shield, gown, and gloves.
targetString: Aye kɔc ke APMP luel wu kɔc ë kacip loi wälë jɔt kï ayanïïn tuany në COVID-19 akɔɔr bïke wum ya kum në alath thïn yenë raan wëi apiɛth thïn

sourceString: If an aerosol-generating procedure is performed, the surgical mask is replaced with an N95 or FFP2 respirator.
targetString: Na loi dïktor yïlac de guyɔɔk ke ka kɔɔr bï alath de wum waar në N95 wenë FFP2

sourceString: Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.
targetString: Acan alath ke gël de tuany yeke cɔl  PPE  alik, akutnhom ye cɔl WHO ë jam wu bï awëër ya liep ku bï ya raan rɛ̈ɛ̈r ke raan tuany yenë lɔ xöt ku bï raan nyin tit të ler yen ɣon de raan nɔŋ COVID-19, bï raan PPE ya tau tenɔŋ yen kë loi, bï raan nɔŋ tok de wum, bï PPE ya bɛi ëke juëc ku bï cëŋ da alath de wum raac nyaai tenɔŋ kɔc kɔ̈k.

sourceString: FROM: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
targetString: TËNƆ̈Ŋ: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia foundation CEO

sourceString: TO: All Wikimedia Foundation staff
targetString: ALƆ TËNË: kɔc ke Wikimedia foundation

sourceString: SUBJECT LINE: [Covid-19] Lightening the load and preparing for the future
targetString: KË JƐMË ATHÖÖR: Ke jɛmë athöör, ë [covid-19] ajuiɛɛr de nïn bï ben tueŋ

sourceString: SEND DATE/TIME: 14 March, 2020, 00:24 UTC
targetString: AKÖLË TUÖC/THÄ: Kol nïn 14, 2020 në thaar 00:24 UTC.

sourceString: LICENSING: CC0: No rights reserved
targetString: Cät: CC0: Acïn yic tɔu në yekënë yic

sourceString: We find ourselves in remarkable circumstances this month.
targetString: Wɔ cï rɔt yök në pïïr peei yic në penë

sourceString: The COVID-19 epidemic is something that makes clear our global human interconnectedness and the responsibilities we have to one another.
targetString: Tuany ye cɔl COVID-19 acï kɔc paakic arëëtic ku mäkthulia tɔ̈ kenë wuɔk në wɔ pɛ̈c.

sourceString: We don't have precedent for its challenges, but we do know that our best response relies on the sort of global empathy, cooperation, and community building that sits at the heart of this organization.
targetString: Ɣok cën kë lë bï wuɔk lui thïn ke ye kë thɛɛr arëëtic, ku aŋicku kë buk looi atɔ̈u kë bï pinynhom tak bï looi, buk lui ë tök, ku yïŋde wut, mɛ̈n ic, ku  buöth akut tɔ̈u aguiɛr kën puöu.

sourceString: The camaraderie and care we have seen among all of our colleagues over email, calls, and chats is a remarkable validation of the incredible humans we are fortunate enough to work with.
targetString: Luɔi cï kɔc lui kenë loi apiɛth arëëtic. Acï wɔ gaar në cabaka nyin ku ka cï cɔl në telepun. Ë kënë ecï ceŋ piɛth nyuɔɔth

sourceString: I couldn't be more grateful and proud to count you all as colleagues.
targetString: Acï lë ba piɔ̈u miɛt acan ba we kuen

sourceString: Last week, someone shared with me their appreciation for our work.
targetString: Në wïïk wan cï lɔ, ke raan acï wɔ leec në luɔɔi cukku loi

sourceString: They reminded me how meaningful it is for the world to be able to turn to Wikipedia right now, and what a powerful symbol it is for this critical resource to remain online and available to all.
